Attachments: (no subject).eml.msg
You don't often get email from jeremy@iron512.com. Learn why this is important
Jeremy Lambert 
Market Development RepresentativeIron Workers Local 5123752 Midway Rd Hermantown, MN 55810218-391-2295jeremy@iron512.com

1 
 To: consumer.puc@state.mn.us  (MPUC Docket # 24-198  
(Proposed acquisition of Minnesota Power / Allete by BlackRock) 
JT Haines, Duluth, MN 
April 17, 2025 
 
Dear Commissioners, 
My name is JT Haines, I am a Minnesota Power ratepayer and resident of northern 
Minnesota. I am also a lawyer with experience in private equity and mergers & acquisitions, 
having worked as an associate for ﬁve years in the corporate department of a major 
Minneapolis law ﬁrm.1 Thank you for considering my comment about the proposed 
acquisition by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Blackrock/Global 
Infrastructure Partners (GIP) (together, “Blackrock”) of Allete / Minnesota Power (MP). I urge 
you to ﬁnd this proposed acquisition of MP by Blackrock not in the public interest. 
The three main points I want to make in this comment are in regard to MP’s claims in this 
docket about needing more infrastructure and more capital to build that infrastructure. 
MP’s recent IRP asserts the need for 1100MW of new capacity,2 including 1000MW of new 
gas. (1) What is missing from MP’s simpliﬁed rationale is that MP itself actively promotes  
this additional demand . MP has a ﬁnancial interest in creating the very demand that it is 
claiming as a justiﬁcation for this proposed acquisition. Testimony about the need for more 
capital and infrastructure from MP should be discounted. (2) Blackrock owns stakes in 
current and potential MP customers, creating a clear incentive for self-dealing that is in 
violation of the public interest and reason alone to reject this proposed acquisition. (3) 
Annual global climate emissions continue to increase, making MPs claims about the need 
for this transaction to support new gas infrastructure further against the public interest. 
(1) MP promotes the demand it claims as justiﬁcation for the proposed acquisition. 
As an investor-owned utility, Minnesota Power has a direct proﬁt interest in increasing load 
and infrastructure build. This is because the proﬁt allowed for the regulated entity is 
directly related to the value of assets. “The higher the assets, the higher the total 
proﬁt…There is a clear incentive to build the most expensive infrastructure possible, 
 
1 I practiced as an attorney in the corporate department of the Minneapolis law ﬁrm of Dorsey & Whitney LLP 
from 2005-2010. Representative ﬁle involvement includes the sale of cheese assets by Land O’Lakes to 
Saputo, Inc., for $216 million. https://www.reuters.com/article/business/saputo-buys-land-olakes-cheese-
unit-for-216-mln-idUSN21271056/   
2 Minesota Power 2025-2039 Integrated Resource Plan, March 3, 2025 | MPUC Docket No. E015/RP-25-127 
2 
 because it (almost) automatically translates into bigger proﬁts.”3 As one former employer 
quipped recently in a discussion of this docket, “anything to spin another turbine.” 
Local observation of MP over the years bears this out. We have witnessed MP partner with 
corporate interests to promote projects like Enbridge’s Line 3 and Glencore’s PolyMet 
vociferously. We have seen how MP executives support local politicians who support these 
potential new Large Industrial customers. We have seen MP use modeling in its IRP ﬁlings 
that include these potential new customers (like Glencore/PolyMet) and use that modeling 
as justiﬁcation for new infrastructure (like the Nemadji Trail Energy Center). We have seen 
MP place its very own representatives in elected o Ưice (like the Duluth City Council4) and 
on the Boards of Directors of potential new customers (like Glencore/PolyMet5).  
An event this month in Saint Paul illustrates this dynamic. MP, alongside current LI 
customers USS and Cli Ưs, as well as  potential new Large Industrial (LI) customers Twin 
Metals, NewRange Copper Nickel (the re-branded PolyMet), and Mining Minnesota 
sponsored an event in St. Paul that was hosted by six area state legislators.6 
 
 
3 See Robinson, Buddy, Testimony to Public Utilities Commission regarding the proposed acquisition of 
Allete/Minnesota Power. Docket # 24-198. 
4 MP business development manager Arik Forsman sits on the Duluth City Council. 
https://www.linkedin.com/in/arikforsman/   
5 Al Hodnick, President of Allete from 2009 to 2019 has served on the Board of PolyMet Mining since 2011. 
https://www.allete.com/Governance/Hodnik  https://polymetmining.com/about-polymet-mining-
corp/leadership/alan-r-hodnik/   
6 https://www.linkedin.com/company/mining-minnesota/posts/?feedView=all   

3 
 The Jobs for Minnesotans Board – also a sponsor -- includes representatives from 
Minnesota Power, the Building and Construction Trades, the Chamber of Commerce, and 
additional elected o Ưicials.7 
 
 
 
I have personally observed over ten years that, together, these associations exert 
signiﬁcant political pressure on local politicians, which creates political pressure at the 
state level, which creates pressure on our regulatory decision-making. It is clear that MP’s 
direct ﬁnancial interest in promoting new consumption alongside current and potential 
customers is superordinate to – and therefore in conﬂict with -- the broader public interest. 
As discussed in the next section, it should be taken as a given that ownership by Blackrock 
would make this problem worse. 
 
 
7 https://jobsforminnesotans.org/about/board/   

4 
 (2) BlackRock owns stakes in current and prospective MP customers, exacerbating 
pressures on institutions, and presenting a clear risk of self-dealing.  
In a word, MP already promotes new pipelines and copper mines in Minnesota for its own 
business reasons that are not necessarily in the broader public interest, exerting signiﬁcant 
political pressure to do so. Meanwhile, Blackrock owns stakes in three of MPs largest 
current customers: Cleveland Cli Ưs, US Steel, and Enbridge , and 6% of Glencore (which 
owns PolyMet).8 If Blackrock is allowed to acquire MP, it would own ﬁnancial stakes in 
these very same potential pipeline and copper mine customers that MP already promotes. 
This would create even more incentive for the public utility to push them in the regulatory 
process whatever the ultimate impact on the public interest.  
The pressure on Minnesota’s local politicians and regulatory institutions is already intense, 
and we know the current structure already disempowers local elected o Ưicials and 
ratepayers. Allowing Blackrock – with its $11T under management -- to own MP while it also 
owns signiﬁcant stakes in the LI customers it serves would clearly exacerbate these 
pressures against the public interest. This clear incentive for self-dealing is reason enough 
alone to reject this proposed acquisition. 
(3) Underlying All of This, Global Emissions Continue to Increase  
Underlying this entire picture of a growth agenda being out of step with public interest is 
the bigger picture of carbon emissions worldwide. Global carbon emissions continue to 
increase year over year, and overall carbon content in the atmosphere continues to 
increase as well. This global context further dictates that Blackrock’s agenda, along with 
MP customers in which it owns a stake, of “more” is not in the public interest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
8 https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/climate-energy/blackrock-voted-against-glencores-climate-
progress-report-2023-09-06/   
5 
 Annual carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions worldwide from 1940 to 20249 
 
10 
 
9 Statista, January 25, 2025 https://www.statista.com/statistics/276629/global-co2-emissions/   
10 National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, 2022. https://www.noaa.gov/news-release/carbon-
dioxide-now-more-than-50-higher-than-pre-industrial-levels   

6 
 Conclusion 
The public has an interest in clean energy, in conservation, in how energy is distributed, in 
equity, in rates, in local control, arguably in reducing energy consumption overall. An 
investor-owned utility has an interest in proﬁt and – apparently – in selling more energy in 
general. Allowing Blackrock – with its $11T under management -- to own Minnesota Power 
while it also owns signiﬁcant stakes in the large industrial customers would supercharge 
these incentives to bring more load and infrastructure online and further strain regulatory 
institutions and local control. We do not need to wait for these things to happen to know 
that they will happen. We can simply know that they will happen based on the evidence 
that abounds around us. 
I urge you to ﬁnd this proposed transaction not in the public interest . If anything, to truly 
align the interests of MP with the public interest, we should be moving in the direction of 
cooperative or public ownership.  
Finally, I would invite you to give no weight to the dates set forth in the proposed purchase 
agreement in terms of your decision-making timelines. Those dates are the business of the 
parties to the contract, not the State of Minnesota, and should not bear any relevance to 
Minnesota’s public decision making. 
Thank you. 
JT Haines 
Duluth, Minnesota 
(612) 743-7781

On behalf of ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power, attached please find Minnesota

The information designated within this Initial Post-Hearing Brief as nonpublic has

consider to be highly sensitive and trade secret as defined by Minn. Stat. § 13.37, subd. 
1(b). The information derives independent economic value from not being generally 
known to, or readily ascertainable by proper means by, others who could obtain economic 
advantage from its disclosure or use and the Company maintains these materials as trade

highly confidential, trade secret nature of the data is available in the underlying 
documents cited in the Initial Brief.

       Carly Krause

FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by

and Global Infrastructure Partners  MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MINNESOTA POWER’S INITIAL BRIEF  
May 1, 2025  
TAFT STETTINIUS & HOLLISTER LLP  
Elizabeth M. Brama  
Kodi Jean Verhalen  
2200 IDS Center  
80 South Eighth Street  
Minneapolis, MN 55402  
Telephone:  (612) 977 -8400

PUBLIC DOCUMENT 
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET DATA EXCISED

III.ISSUES TO BE ADDRESSED  ................................ ................................ ...............  11

COMMITMENTS WARRANT APPROVAL OF THE ACQUISITION  .......................  13
A. Financial Commitments to Minnesota Power  ................................ .................  13
B. Capital Structure (Equity and Debt)  ................................ ................................  20
C. Corporate Separateness/Ring Fencing  ................................ ..........................  27

VI.MINNESOTA POWER’S UNION AND NON -UNION WORKFORCES ACTIVELY
SUPPORT THE ACQUISITION AND ARE BENEFITTED BY IT.  ...........................  72
VII.A KEY PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITION IS TO ENSURE MINNESOTA POWER
HAS THE CAPITAL NEEDED TO COMPLY WITH THE CARBON -FREE
STANDARD.  ................................ ................................ ................................ ...........  72
VIII.  THE PROPOSED TRANSACTION IS CONSISTENT WITH THE PUBLIC
INTEREST, PARTICULARLY GIVEN THE COMMITMENTS IN THE RECORD.  .. 77
IX.CONCLUSION  ................................ ................................ ................................ ........  79
ATTACHMENT S 
Attachment A 
Attachment B Petitioners’ Proposed Commitments ( Cady Rebuttal Schedule 1 
and Lapson Direct Schedule 3)  
Attachment H to Petition - Reporting Transparency 
1 I. INTRODUCTION
In this docket, ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power1 seeks approval of the
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission ( “Commission ”) for the Company to  be acquired 
by Global Infrastructure Partners ( “GIP”) and Canada Pension Plan Investments Board 
(“CPP Investments ”) (GIP and CPP Investments are, collectively, the “Partners ” to the 
“Acquisition” ) – and in doing so, approving what may be the most significant transaction 
in Minnesota Power’s history  to strengthen the Company  and support its vision for a 
sustainable , clean energy future.  
It is important to underscore, as the Company’s detailed testimony shows, that the 
decision to enter into the Acquisition was the result of a lengthy, robust,  and carefully 
thought -out and executed process. Consistent with its fiduciary duties to the Company 
and with a laser focus on the needs of customers and employees, t he current ALLETE 
Board of Directors  (“ALLETE Board”) , chaired by its Chief Executive Officer, sought a 
path that would enable  Minnesota Power to finance its obligations to continue providing 
safe and reliable service despite aging infrastructure and system investment needs, its 
requirement to meet the State of Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard, and to provide long -
term financial stability to the Company.  It did not pursue an auction process; nor was the 
Board constrained in its options as some intervenors have (incorrectly) claimed in this 
proceeding. Rather, Company leadership sought out, narrowed down to, and ultimately 
chose pa rtners with the financial capability, dedication, stable operations, commitment to 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Initial Brief “Minnesota 
Power ” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically defined, 
references to “ALLETE ” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota Power 
and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company ” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
2 
 state regulation, aligned vision, and commitment to ALLETE as it exists today – allowing 
the Company to maintain its customer focus, employee commitment, location and 
community presence, management and leadership, operations and strategy, and 
continuing fo cus on the clean energy transition.2 Moreover, the Partners worked together 
to establish a post-Acquisition governance  structure  in which no one Partner will have a 
majority control of the future ALLETE Board and each Partner acts as a check on the 
other.3 Throughout this regulatory process, the Partners have made clear they support 
and are aligned with Minnesota Power’s role and place before the Commission , and with 
the Company’s continuing relationships with its stakeholders.  
The Commission has long acknowledged that Minnesota Power, whose capital 
plan makes up more than 87 percent  of ALLETE,4 has a unique customer base and a 
uniquely risky profile.5 Large, energy -intensive industrial customers make up 56 percent 
of Minnesota Power’s retail sales , and demand electricity 24 hours a day, seven days a 
week  – except that their businesses involve  highly cyclical operations .6 Despite this 
cyclicality, Minnesota Power has an ongoing obligation to ensure the integrity of its assets 
and continue with the clean energy transition – which requires more equity capital  in the 
next five years than ALLETE has had to raise in its 75 years of public market 
 
2 Ex. MP -1 at Attachment L Page 55 -59 (Petition); Ex. MP -9 at 8 (Cady Direct).  
3 Ex. MP -14 at 21 (Bram Direct).  
4 Ex. MP -11 at 3 (Taran Direct) (The Company’s “five -year capital expenditure projections for regulated 
operations . . . accounted for 87 percent of the ALLETE Consolidated capital expenditures.”)  
5 In the Matter of the Application of Minnesota Power for Authority to Increase Rates for Electric Service in 
Minnesota , Docket No. E015/GR -16-644, FINDINGS OF FACT, CONCLUSIONS , AND ORDER  at 53 (March 12, 
2018); In the Matter of the Application of Minnesota Power for Authority to Increase Rates for Electric 
Service in Minnesota , Docket No. E015/GR -21-335, FINDINGS OF FACT, CONCLUSIONS , AND ORDER  at 63 
(Feb. 28, 2023).   
6 Ex. MP -45 at 11 (ALLETE, Inc. 2024 Form 10 -K) (“In 2024, industrial customers represented 56 percent 
of total regulated utility [kilowatt -hour] sales.”)  
 
3 
 participation.7 More than half of the new capital expenditures anticipated in the next five 
years have already been approved by the Commission through new transmission projects 
necessary to serve the public;8 this total does not account for additional future generation 
needs with coal retirements on the known horizon. Requiring ALLETE to raise close to 
this level of capital in the public markets  that are  inherently subject to volatility and  market 
disruption – which would be particularly acute right now but for the pending Acquisition – 
not only places the Company’s ability to obtain sufficient equity at very high risk, but also 
affects the cost of capital to customers. By pursuing the Acquisition with these Partners, 
the Company is mitigat ing these risks for customers .  
At the same time, the Company fully understand s that the Partners , like any 
investor,  seek the kind of predictable, fair returns historically approved by the Commission  
and anticipate that there are benefits  of owning an energy company that increases its 
value by leaning into clean, reliable, renewable power , customer service,  and ensuring 
adequate infrastructure to support these goals . Both Minnesota Power and the Partners 
have acknowledged repeatedly throughout this proceeding that any of their goals, 
assumptions, scenarios, or plans regarding utility resource development, customer 
programs, rates, returns on investment, capital structure and financing/borrowing, any 
subsequent acquisition, and more are all subject to Commission and stakeholder review 
and ultimately the decisions of the Commission.  In short, the Partners are acquiring an 
established company within a known regulatory construct – not any particular financial 
scenario or outcome.   
 
7 Ex. MP -29 at 3 (Taran Rebuttal). It is important to underscore that Minnesota Power was only first traded 
on the NY Stock Exchange in 1950; before that time, it was a private investor -owned utility.  
8 Ex. MP -29 at 13 -14 (Taran Rebuttal).  
 
4 
 Parties to this proceeding narrowly focus on only two perceived potential benefits: 
access to capital, and partner expertise.9 Access to capital is the reason for the 
Acquisition, but neither of these are the sole benefits of it.  Nor is the standard for approval 
whether the  Acquisition is ne cessary , but rather whether the Acquisition is in the public 
interest.10 There is extensive  speculation in  the record about whether the size of the 
Company’s capital plans is too large or will play out as currently forecast  and whether it 
is better to access  capital in the public markets  simply because that is what ALLETE has 
done in the past.  Even if these concerns were substantiated by more than speculation in 
testimony (which they are not), they miss the fundamental point:  Even if Minnesota 
Power’s capital needs are ultimately lower than anticipated, and even if the Company 
could access capital in the public markets, as the Department  of Commerce ’s (the 
“Department”)  witne ss agreed customers would still receive substantial benefits from this 
transaction that simply are not possible in the public markets . These include  (but are in 
no way limited to):  
• Committed funding of Minnesota Power’s five -year capital plan.11  
• Guarantee of no dividends outside of ALLETE’s capital structure regardless of 
the amount of capital needs, unless the Company has an investor -grade credit 
rating.12  
• Reduction of costs in the form of no investor relations or flotation costs and 
reduced Board of Directors’ costs.13  
• Absorption of $3.5 million of arrears from Minnesota Power’s most vulnerable 
customers.14  
 
9 See Ex. DOC -304 at 2, 24 (Addonizio Surrebuttal); Ex. OAG -402 at 5 (Lebens Surrebuttal).  
10 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  
11 Evid. Hrg. Tr. at 569:9 -569:14 (April 2, 2025 ) (Addonizio).  
12 Id. at 569:21-570:14.  
13 Id. at 570:15 -570:24  
14 Id. at 570:25 -571:6.  
 
5 
 • No reduction to any of Minnesota Power’s affordability programs for low -income 
customers , regardless of other circumstances facing the Company.15  
• No reduction to Minnesota Power’s best in class low-income program eligibility 
requirements , regardless of other circumstances facing the Company .16  
• Maintaining the same level of charitable contributions regardless of whether the 
Company experiences reduced revenues or higher costs.17  
• Two years of the same or better compensation or benefits in ratified contracts 
with local union workers.18  
• Commitment to maintaining ALLETE’s headquarters in Duluth, Minnesota , 
which does not currently exist .19  
• Commitment to maintaining ALLETE’s current senior management , which does 
not currently exist .20  
Certain parties also raise concerns about perceived risks or possible negative 
effects of the Acquisition.  What is inherently lacking in intervenor testimony, however, is 
a balancing of the actual likelihood of those concerns occurring, analysis of whether and 
to what extent such perceived risks also apply to publicly -traded investor -owned utilities 
(including those currently regulated by the Commission), and whether or to wh at extent 
either the Commission’s inherent authority or the additional protections proposed in this 
proceeding (or both) mitigate or remove the perceived risk.  Additionally, intervening 
parties raise conflicting concerns.  As key examples:  
• At least one party expresses concern the  Company should not make the level of 
investments necessary to meet the Carbon Free  Standard ( “CFS”)21 and the 
resulting or modeled potential utility rates on the one hand,22 whereas other parties 
 
15 Id. at 571:7 -571:17.  
16 Id. 
17 Id. 
18 Id. at 572:1 -572:24.  
19 Id.  
20 Id.  
21 Ex. LPI -1002 at 43 (Walters Direct).  
22 Ex. LPI -1002 at 43 (Walters Direct); Ex. OAG -402 at 11 -12. Indeed, the LPI collation of large power 
customers seems most concerned about the costs of the CFS – which are not dependent on the Acquisition 
– and wanting “net benefits ” for these industrial customers rather than the applicable statutory standard.  
 
6 
 reflect concern the Company might not make (or the Partners might not fund) the 
level of investments necessary to meet the C FS.23 Not only is it up to the 
Commission to decide what level and kinds of utility investments to approve – and 
to evaluate and re -evaluate regularly through resource plans, permitting, rate 
cases, rider filings, and the like – but each of these concerns exist s equally in the 
public markets.  
• Similarly, Sierra Club raises the potential for the Partners to sell their shares in 
ALLETE before the end of the cessation of coal -fired generation at the Boswell 
Energy Center24 while simply ignoring the equivalent potential (and more likely 
scenario given the Partners’ statements in this proceeding) for the Partners to see 
the cessation of coal -fired generation at the Boswell Energy Center through to its 
completion  and that the Partners would need Commission approval to exit if and 
when they seek to do so .25 In contrast, current shareholders of ALLETE could exit 
their ownership at any time without Commission approval , including those 
shareholders that currently own outsized percentages of the Company.  
• The Department  expresses concern about the level of debt that might be taken on 
at the Alloy Parent LLC (“Alloy Parent”)26 level, without acknowledging the 
Commission’s oversight of both Minnesota Power and ALLETE’s capital structure, 
that ALLETE’s current equity ratio is materially higher than other utility holding 
companies, and that the Partners have objective financial in centives to not over -
leverage their own investment. The parties also fail to constructively evaluate the 
specifics of the ring -fencing provisions (including the potential to withhold 
dividends if ALLETE is not financially healthy) offered by the Partners a nd the 
Company.  
• Multiple parties raise concerns the Partners might not adhere to their commitment 
to fund Minnesota Power’s five -year plan. However, each ignores that the public 
markets provide literally no assurance of funding any particular company’s capital 
plan, and no party gives credence to the Commission’s authority and statutory 
rights to enforce commitments embodied in its own orders.  
• Multiple parties raised concerns that the Partners would be appointing certain 
ALLETE Board directors in addition to the independent directors. Such critique 
ignores that ALLETE’s Board is currently made up of directors elected by the 
current shareholders. Further, this critique ignores that today, any one shareholder 
could either run a campaign for their preferred director to be elected or even 
 
23 Ex. Sierra Club -1100 at 33 -34 (Lane Direct).  
24 Ex. Sierra Club -1100 at 15 (Lane Direct); Ex. Sierra Club -1102 at 14 (Corrected Lane Surrebuttal).  
25 Evid. Hrg. Tr. at 826:1 -826:24 (April 3, 2025 ) (Lane ). Nor is there any particular timeline for the Partners ’ 
exit; see Footnote 311 to this Initial Brief, infra.  
26 Alloy Parent is the Partner -created entity that will acquire all shares of ALLETE and through which GIP 
and CPP Investment will hold their ownership of ALLETE. Petition at 1, 10-11. 
 
7 
 acquire sufficient shares to place their preferred director or directors on the 
ALLETE Board.  
• The Department’s claimed concerns about affiliated interests do not recognize that 
the Company and Partners are proposing affiliated interest protections well beyond 
those the Commission currently requires for publicly -owned utilities and their 
investors, and that the Commission will have ongoing authority to assess and 
approve any contract, agreement, or cost that is affected by any affiliated interest 
consideration.  
In contrast, the Company and the Partners reviewed the concerns of the parties in 
testimony, and provided additional objective, detailed commitments, organized by type of 
concern, to constructively address regulatory feedback with the appropriate considera tion 
of any particular risk identified by the parties. Specifically, the Company and Partners 
identified concerns raised in testimony into the following areas and identified 
commitments in each to significantly mitigate or remove such concerns altogether , which 
are provided in ATTACHMENT A  to this Brief . These topical areas include:  
• Financial Commitments to Minnesota Power

II. STANDARD OF REVIEW  
The proposed Acquisition  is governed by  Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, which requires 
Commission approval before  a public utility  may “sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as 
an operating unit or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, 
or merge or consolidate with another public utility or transmission company operating in 
this state .” Under this statute, the Commission must assess whether the  Acquisition  is 
“consistent with the public interest .”30 If the Commission finds that the Acquisition  is 
consistent with the public interest, it  must issue an order approving the Acquisition .31 
To determine if the Acquisition  is “consistent with the public interest, perceived 
detriments or concerns must be weighed against perceived benefits to the public. If the 
perceived detriments do not outweigh the perceived benefits, the merger is deemed to be 
‘consistent with the public interest. ’”32 Although the Commission uses a balancing test to

 determine if the Acquisition  is consistent with the public interest,33 a finding that the 
Acquisition  results in net benefits is not required . Rather, in prior cases, the  Commission 
has consistently held that  the public interest standard  does not require an affirmative 
finding of public benefit, but requires  only a finding that a transaction is compatible with 
the public interest.34 The Commission has also stated that Minn. Stat. §  216B.50 “does 
not require that proposed mergers affirmatively benefit ratepayers or the public or that 
they otherwise promote the public interest. ”35 To satisfy this standard, the Acquisition  
merely “cannot contravene the public interest . . . and must be shown to be compatible 
with it. ”36

IV. CONSIDERATION OF BENEFITS, POTENTIAL HARMS, AND PROPOSED 
COMMITMENTS WARRANT APPROVAL OF THE ACQUISITION45  
As noted above, the  Commission ordered the evaluation of the “potential harms to 
the public interest ” and the “potential benefits to ratepayers ” in this proceeding. It is 
important to ground the evaluation of the Acquisition in the following: all risks raised to 
this point are “potential ” whereas the benefits of the Acquisition are real and tangible. Not 
only are there benefits for Minnesota Power’s customers, but there are benefits for 
Minnesota Power’s employees, the local economies within Minnesota Power’s service 
territory, and Minneso ta as a whole. These cannot be ignored , as the agencies and certain 
intervening parties advocate.  Below , the Co mpany walks through the risks and potential 
harms identified by varying parties to the proceeding  and balances them against the 
benefits – including both affirmative new advantages to stakeholders and carefully 
structured protections against perceived potential harm. Taken individually and as a 
whole, there can be no doubt the Acquisition is a net ben efit to the public interest – even 
exceeding the “consistent with the  public interest ” standard .

this is so that ALLETE , whose capital needs are driven by Minnesota Power , can meet

B. Capital Structure (Equity and Debt)  
As explained by Witness Taran , utilities typically fund their operations through a 
mix of equity and debt to balance financial considerations and risk management.84 While 
debt financing is generally lower cost than equity financing,  it adds financial risk  due to 
the obligation to make interest payments , which places pressure on  credit ratings .85 Thus, 
utilities seek  a balanced capital structure that  allows for just and reasonable rates  while 
maintaining access to  capital at competitive rates  on behalf of customers.86 Importantly,

C. Corporate Separateness/Ring Fencing  
Through the course of this proceeding, ALLETE and the Partners made a number 
of commitments , on top of those previously existing within ALLETE,  relating to protecting 
Minnesota Power from risks associated with the claimed business and financial risks of 
the Acquisition. These commitments provide an important benefit: they demonstrate that 
Minnesota Power and its customers will be appropriately protected and separated from 
any business and financial risks  perceived to be associated with the Partners, as 
suggested by various agencies and intervenors in this proceeding. Further, Witness 
Lapson explained how these com mitments minimize potential harm from the 
Transaction.124  
 
123 Id. 
124 Ex. MP -36 at 4 (Lapson Rebuttal).  
28 1. The Ring -fencing Commitments
Ring-fencing is a term used to describe arrangements that keep a regulated utility 
business separate from the non -utility affiliates or holding company parent of the utility. 
As Witness Lapson explained, “ring-fencing mechanisms have been  successfully used to 
protect utilities from risky parents or affiliated companies and have  proven effective in 
allowing the Protected Companies to carry out their mandate to serve  present and future 
customers. ”125 
Many of ALLETE’s ring -fencing commitments were established at pages 19 -20 of 
the Petition.126 The key commitments include : 
•ALLETE and Alloy Parent will maintain separate books and records, agree to
prohibitions against loans or pledges of assets of ALLETE without regulatory
approval, and generally hold ALLETE harmless from any business and financial
risk exposures associated w ith Alloy Parent or its subsidiaries or affiliates (other
than any subsidiary of ALLETE);
•ALLETE and Alloy Parent will maintain separate stock and debt;
•Neither ALLETE nor Alloy  Parent shall provide direct credit support to a credit
facility of  the other through a guarantee, and none of ALLETE’s credit facilities
shall include any  cross -default provision whereby a default under any of Alloy
Parent’s credit facilities would  cause a default under any of ALLETE’s credit
facilities;
•ALLETE will maintain its own corporate and debt rating, and its own ratings for
long-term debt;  and
•ALLETE will be structured such that, in the event of a bankruptcy of Alloy Parent
or any of its subsidiaries or affiliates (other than ALLETE and its subsidiaries),
a bankruptcy court will not consolidate the assets and liabilities of ALLETE with
Alloy Parent or any Alloy  Parent entity, and except as allowed by law, any costs
incurred as a result of the bankruptcy of Alloy Parent or any Alloy Parent entity
cannot be sought from ALLETE.127

 2. Witness Lapson’s Analysis of the Ring -Fencing Commitments  
Witness Lapson has extensive experience analyzing the adequacy and 
appropriateness of ring -fencing measures in the context of a utility transaction.134 In 
contrast to witnesses of the agencies and the intervening parties, Witness Lapson has 
developed a set of systematic and comprehensive standards regarding the protection of 
a company from adversity as a result of its affiliation with a parent or affilia ted entities that 
has been used in multiple regulatory proceedings where acquisitions have been approved 
by state regulatory commissions.135 
Witness Lapson’s framework has two tracks. Track I contains practices that allow 
the Protected Company136 to preserve its own identity, remain viable, fund itself, resist 
incurring liabilities unrelated to its own business, and defend its own assets and liabilities 
even if its parent or an affiliate is in distress.137 Track II contains practices that protect a 
company from involuntary consolidation by a bankruptcy court with its parent or affiliate 
in the parent or affiliate’s bankruptcy proceeding.138 
For the Acquisition, Witness Lapson analyzed the ring -fencing commitments made 
by ALLETE and the Partners. In doing  so, Witness Lapson  also considered the 
protections that exist because of the Commission’s regulatory authority over Minnesota 
Power, which will remain unchanged if the Acquisition is approved by the Commission. 
Witness Lapson concluded that the ring -fencing commitments are “strong ”139 and that

D. Books and Records  
Minnesota law provides that the Commission has access to, and can examine, all 
of Minnesota Power’s books and finances.159 In addition, Minnesota Power provides 
extremely detailed and wide -ranging financial information to the Commission in its rate 
cases, rider proceedings, jurisdictional annual reports  and annual affiliated interest filings , 
integrated resource planning ( “IRP”) and integrated distribution planning ( “IDP”) 
proceedings, annual capital structure filings, and numerous other compliance filings. All 
of this information is made available to the OAG and the Department  as well as the 
Commission , and nearly all of it is available to the general public.

E. Affiliated Interests  
The Commission and Minnesota public  utilities have long interpreted Minn. Stat. 
§ 216B.48 and the associated rules governing affiliated interests to apply when an affiliate 
owned in whole or in part by the public utility or the public utility holding company contracts 
with the public utilit y governed by the Commission. The purpose of these requirements  is 
to allow the Commission to ensure that agreements between affiliated companies are 
reasonable and to identify potential self -dealing that could harm custo mers. Consistent 
with Minnesota law, Minnesota Power has filed with the Commission (a) affiliated interest 
agreements and tax sharing agreements between it and subsidiaries of ALLETE  and (b)  
an annual  Affiliated Interest Annual Report ( “Annual Affiliate Report ”). The Annual Affiliate 
Report lists all shareholders that own greater than five percent  of the outstanding shares 
of ALLETE’s stock . Consistent with longstanding practice before the Commission, 
 
171 Ex. MP -35 at 13 -14 (Anderson Rebuttal).  
172 Ex. MP -35 at 14 (Anderson Rebuttal).  
 
40 
 Minnesota regulated electric utilities have not listed in their Annual Affiliate Report the  
subsidiar ies or affiliate s of any such shareholder.   
Specifically, for a number of years  the shareholders owning more than five percent 
of ALLETE’s outstanding shares have been institutional investors such as BlackRock, 
Inc. ( “BlackRock ”) and The Vanguard Group, Inc. ( “Vanguard ”).173 The Commission has 
not treated other companies owned by BlackRock or Vanguard as being affiliated 
interests with Minnesota Power that required filings with the Commission. The 
Commission has taken this approach not only as to ALLETE, but it has consistently 
applied this treatment in similar instances to other Minnesota utilities.174 Likewise, 
reporting has not been required or anticipated when two separately -owned public utilities, 
each of whose ultimate shares may be held in an amount greater than five percent by the 
same shareholder, contract for business together.175 
The Commission’s approach recognizes that institutional investors are investors, 
not operators of public utilities. The Commission’s approach is reasonable —it ensures 
that enough information is provided to allow stakeholders to analyze affiliated interest 
issues and protect against self -dealing, while avoiding the unworkable task of tracking the 
hundreds or thousands of companies in which institutional investors such as BlackRock 
or Vanguard own a stake. As Commission Staff noted, “It is unlikely that there  are a 
significant number of large or medium -sized publicly -traded companies in the United 
States that Vanguard and/or BlackRock don’t own 5% or more of . . .. Given the nature of

the shares of both ALLETE and Otter Tail Power Company, these utilities do not make an affiliated interest 
filing when the utilities jointly develop a tran smission line project nor do they include such information in 
their Annual Affiliate Reports. S ee Notice of Intent to Construct, Own, and Maintain the Maple River - 
Cuyuna 345 kV Transmission Project LRTP Project #20 , Docket No. E015,ET2,E017/CN -25-109.

 Vanguard and BlackRock, it is likely that virtually every contract that many, if not all our 
investor -owned utilities undertake with a public traded corporation – and some privately 
held businesses – would become ‘affiliated interest’ contracts under the a pproach taken 
by the Department. ”176 
In this proceeding, ALLETE and the Partners are not seeking any change in the 
status quo relating to affiliated interests. Their position is simply that the Commission’s 
current approach should remain unchanged,  and the approach advocated for by the 
Department would require significant changes to reporting and tracking for all Minnesota 
public utilities. Nevertheless, ALLETE and the Partners are offering more than the status 
quo—as described below, they are proposing to provide more information than other 
Minnesota utilities do.  
1. The Company and the Partners Have Taken Steps to Minimize the 
Risk of Affiliated Interests  
The Company  and the Partners provided a detailed explanation of the measures 
they will take to provide information about agreements between affiliated companies and 
to identify potential self -dealing that could harm customers. Specifically, Minnesota Power 
will continue to file all affiliated interest and tax sharing agreements as it has been doing 
and will also continue to file its Annual Affiliate Report.177 The Company committed that 
in that Report, Minnesota Power would  identify all entities directly up the chain of ALLETE 
corporate ownership, from Alloy Parent up to and including CPP Investments  and GIP.178

Department Witness Vavro  expressed concern that the Acquisition will cause 
Minnesota Power to have “hundreds, if not thousands, of new affiliates ,” accusing the 
Partners and Minnesota Power of “unwillingness to support the Commission’s due 
diligence efforts to protect ratepayer [sic] from associate [sic] harm, as set forth in Minn. 
Stat. § 216B.48 . . . . ”184 There are at least three reasons why these arguments are 
misplaced.  
First, Witness Vavro ignored the practical utility of the heightened affiliated interest 
disclosures  to which the Company and the Partners have committed. Indeed, Witness 
Vavro ’s testimony  contains no mention of  the Company’s existing procurement 
protocols.185 As a practical matter, the new process that the Company proposed (using 
questionnaires to identify counterparties more than five percent owned by GIP, CPP  
Investments , or BlackRock, plus separate disclosures of each contract above $1 million 
with those counterparties) should capture all of the agreements and relationships that 
could be of concern.  
In addition, Witness Vavro ignores the Company’s commitment to affiliated interest 
reporting as to GIP and CPP  Investments . Again, the Company committed that in its 
Annual Affiliate Report, it would (a) identify all entities directly up the chain of ALLETE 
corporate ownership, from Alloy Parent up to and including CPP Investments  and GIP 
and (b) continue to identify affiliation with BlackRock in the same way it is currently 
reported .186

customers, employees, and communities. ”190 The ALLETE Board reviews Minnesota 
Power’s “strategy, operational performance, budget, and forecast ” and approves “major

Power’s collaborative approach to stakeholder engagement going 
forward.194

Board interact regarding Minnesota Power’s strategic direction.

G. Ratemaking and Affordability  
The Acquisition supports and enhances the Company’s commitment to fair 
ratemaking practices and customer affordability. While parties speculated about  potential 
negative impacts on customer rates and the economic well -being of customers  based 
largely on generalized fears about private equity or scenario “runs,” the full authority of 
the Commission as well as the substantial  additional commitments by the Partners  fully 
safeguard customers from any concerns about cost or rate implications related to the 
Acquisition.  Rather, t he record evidence demonstrates that there will be improvement to 
the overall well-being of Minnesota Power’s customers if the Acquisition closes , and that 
limiting the Company’s access to capital would only constrain the financial health of the 
Company without real benefit to customers.  Most significantly, the Commission will retain 
full authority over the rates the Company sets in its future rate cases , rider proceedings, 
and other cost recovery matters.

 First, the Partners and Minnesota Power have made fundamental commitments  to 
protect customers against costs attributable to the Acquisition itself . Specifically, 
Minnesota Power and the Partners committed not to seek rate recovery from Minnesota 
Power’s customers for any Acquisition -related costs.211 Moreover, the Partners explicitly 
affirmed that transition costs associated with the Acquisition would not be recovered from 
customers unless such costs are demonstrably offset by corresponding customer 
savings.212 Witness Anderson provided testimony detailing how these costs are being and 
will be tracked to ensure they are not charged to customers.213 Witness Cady further 
underscored this careful tracking at the evidentiary hearing.214 
Second, access to capital and investment in needed infrastructure do not translate 
directly to higher rates in all respects, and certainly not to rates that are not just and 
reasonable. The Commission approves the utility’s major projects in multiple steps – 
throu gh resource plans, certificate of need and permitting proceedings, and various cost 
recovery proceedings. Regardless of the investment, it cannot be included in rates unless 
the Commission approves a request of the utility.  
Additionally, the Company does not ask for all of its investments to be included in 
rates. As noted by Witness Cady, many of the Company’s planned investments are not 
directly rate recovered in rates but rather are shared ( “cost-allocated ”) between different 
entities, typically based on their load (usage) within Midcontinent Independent System 
Operator ( “MISO ”). This is true of four MISO Long -Range Transmission Planning 
(“LRTP ”) projects that form a large portion of Minnesota Power’s capital needs, includin g:

H. Workforce and Labor Protections  
In Order Point 3(F) of the Commission’s Order, the Commission directed the 
parties to develop the record on impacts to and protections for Minnesota Power’s 
bargaining and non -bargaining workforce. The Partners and Minnesota Power have 
established commitme nts that provide security to Minnesota Power’s workforce that 
would not be available absent the transaction. The  two-year post -Acquisition commitment 
to retain the Company’s  current workforce, including bargaining and non -bargaining 
employees and compensat ion packages, is a clear benefit resulting from the proposed 
Acquisition. Minnesota Power not only anticipate s no negative impacts to Minnesota 
Power’s workforce as a result of this Acquisition ,239 but has made commitments that are 
not available absent the Acquisition, with the capital available through the Acquisition a 
key benefit to the Company’s ability to sustain and support its workforce.  The parties to 
this proceeding who represent the Company’s workforce , such as L IUNA , International 
Union  of Operating Engineers Local 49  and North Central States Regional Council of

 I. Core Values and Environmental Commitments  
As demonstrated by much of the prior discussion, as well as the additional 
commitments addressed in this section of this Initial Brief, t he Acquisition aligns with and 
enhances the Company's longstanding core values and steadfast environmental 
commitments . Contrary to speculative concerns raised in this proceeding  about what 
might happen , the record demonstrates that explicit commitments are in place to maintain 
the Company's name and identity, location, community engagement, local accountability, 
and economic development practices.   
CURE Witness Baker expressed apprehension that private equity ownership might 
prioritize short -term financial interests over preserving local economic initiatives, 
employee relations, and established corporate values central to the Company’s 
identity.262 Similarly, Sierra  Club Witness Lane raised concerns about potential risks to 
the Company's environmental objectives, particularly regarding its ability to meet 
Minnesota’s ambitious CFS and planned retirement of coal generation facilities.263 
Witness Lane argued  that changes in ownership could negatively impact the pace or 
effectiveness of the Company’s renewable energy transition.264 
However, none of these witnesses identified any actual experience with these 
Partners, and largely based their concerns on possibility or scenario planning. In contrast, 
the Company  selected these Partners precisely because of their alignment with the 
Company’s deep -seated principles of local engagement, employee well -being, and 
environmental leadership .265 Contrary to claim s that private equity’s high -return targets

 V. THE ACQUISITION HAS BEEN APPROVED BY THE OTHER STATE AND

Order Point 3(E) of the Commission's Order requested an explanation of how any 
“relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory 
Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other state, federal or 
foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration  of the 
[Acquisition ]?”280 The Acquisition  has undergone review in several forums, including the 
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ( “FERC ”) and the Public Service Commission of 
Wisconsin ( “PSCW ”).281 The Company  also submitted the Hart -Scott -Rodino ( “HSR ”) 
premerger notification to the Federal Trade Commission and Antitrust Division of the 
Justice Department . Further,  on August 21, 2024, ALLETE’s shareholders voted to 
approve the proposed Acquisition  with a pproximately 97 percent of shareholder s voting 
in favor of approving the transaction.282 Each of these approvals, particularly those 
granted by agencies of the federal government and the PSCW, are only possible because 
this Acquisition is consistent with the public interest. The Company anticipates that the 
Commission’s approval will be the last step before the Acquisition may close.

The FERC reviewed this transaction under §§ 203(a)(1) and 203(a)( 2) of the 
Federal Power Act (“FPA”) to determine whether it is consistent with the public interest.283

the Acquisition’s approval .285 On January 23, 2025, all parties to the PSCW’s proceeding 
on this matter agreed to waive their respective rights to a contested case hearing and 
executed a Stipulation of Facts and Waiver of Hearing ( “Stipulation ”). The Stipulation was 
agreed to by all parties, including the Citizens Utility Board of Wisconsin, IBEW Local 31, 
Madison Gas and Electric Company, Wisconsin Electric Power Company, and the 
Wisconsin Public Service Corporation.286 On March  13, 2025, the PSCW orally approved 
the transaction, subject to certain conditions, thereby removing any Wisconsin -specific 
barriers .287 All necessary state -level approvals in Wisconsin are thus complete.  No party 
to this proceeding has raised issues with respect to the Wisconsin approval.

HAS THE CAPITAL NEEDED TO COMPLY WITH THE CARBON -FREE 
STANDARD .291 
Order Point 3(G) of the Order directs the record to be developed on “How will the 
acquisition impact Minnesota Power's ability to comply with the carbon -free standard 
under § 216B.1691, including any modifications of plans associated with the Nemadji Trail 
Energy Center? ” As discussed throughout this proceeding, t he primary goal of the 
Acquisition is to provide the Company with a reliable stream of significant additional equity

 capital that will allow the Company to expand its investments in clean energy technologies 
to comply with the C FS.292 Minnesota Power is aware that company operations alone 
would be insufficient to produce the necessary cash flow to fund the capital investments 
to comply with the CFS.293 The Company’s five -year plan demonstrates a significant need 
for additional capital, in the form of an approximately 3.8 -times increase in regulated 
investments compared to the Company’s historical ten -year average.294 The Acquisition 
best positions the Company to achieve its goals and comply with the CFS because it 
provides the Company with a committed and reliable stream of equity capital to invest in 
clean energy technologies while maintaining safe, reliable, and affordable service to 
Minnesota Power customers.   
Consideration of the benefits of the Acquisition to enable meeting the CFS also 
requires consideration of the risks of not meeting the CFS without the Partners’ support.  
Absent the Acquisition, it is unclear whether  the Company would be able to access the 
capital it needs to invest in clean energy technologies , particularly given the cyclicality of 
the public markets, public stockholders’ demands for regular quarterly dividends 
regardless of conditions facing the Company and its revenue streams, and the pri ce the 
Company can obtain on public stock issuances if it needs to issue large quantities on a 
regular basis.295 Without the Acquisition, compliance with the CFS may not be possible 
for Minnesota Power.

21.At the request of EnergyCENTS Coalition, Minnesota Power and the Partners
affirm their understanding that the budget billing provisions in Minnesota Statutes
§216B.098, subdivisions 2 and 3, refer to all residential customers and is not
limited to those who are formally income -qualified. This is consistent with
Minnesota Power’s electric service regulations and practices.Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  While this is currently Minnesota Power’s practice, there is no regulatory requirement that 
Minnesota Power is prohibited from requesting that only those who are income -qualified be 
covered under the budget billing provisions of Minnesota Statutes. This commitment assures 
customers of the Company’s and the Partners’ understanding of this provision.  
22.For as long as Minnesota Power is owned by the Partners, ALLETE’s contributions
to the Minnesota Power Foundation will not be reduced.Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.I 
Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  This commitment ensures that Acquisition by the Partners will not have any negative impact 
on funding at the Minnesota Power Foundation, which provides impactful grant funding to 
communities  throughout Minnesota Power’s service territory. The Partners commit to 
providing the same level of support to local communities.  
23.Minnesota Power will not seek rate recovery of flotation costs beginning with its
next rate case and continuing so long as the Partners own Alloy.Taran Rebuttal Sec. III.A. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  Minnesota Power would incur significant flotation costs if issuing equity in public markets and 
would need to seek recovery in future  rate cases. With the Acquisition, flotation costs will no 
longer be included in the cost of service, to the benefit of customers.  
24.Minnesota Power  will not seek rate recovery of Investor Relations costs beginning
with its next rate case  and continuing so long as the Partners own Alloy .Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  
Taran Rebuttal Sec. III.A. Following approval of the Acquisition, Minnesota Power will continue to have Investor 
Relations costs for some time, but this commitment ensures that they will not be recovered from 
customers. If the Acquisition is not approved, Minnesota Power will continue to need an 
Investor Relations team and would seek recovery of those associated costs in its next and future 
rate cases. These costs will continue beyond the closing of the Acquisition, but they will no 
longer be a cost to customers.  
25.The Partners will not charge fees for any business management or consulting
services provided to ALLETE or Minnesota Power .Alley Rebuttal Sec. III. C. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  This commitment ensures that any  business management or consulting services provided by the 
Partners  will not result in any costs to Minnesota Power customers.  Third party consulting costs 
that contribute to the Company’s utility operations are otherwise appropriate included in the 
cost of service.  
26.For as long as M innesota Power is owned by the Partners, M innesota Power  will
not request rate recovery of board compensation or expenses for any board member
not independent from the Partners.Alley Rebuttal Sec. III. C. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.   Minnesota Power’s rates include costs for  director  compensation and  expenses . After the 
Acquisition, this commitment will ensure that these costs are not requested for board 
compensation or expenses that are not independent from the Partners.  
27.The Company will have the burden to prove in its next rate case that no transaction
costs, nor the costs identified in the Ratemaking section of this proposal for
exclusion from future rate cases, are included in the cost of service to be recovered
from cu stomers.Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  This commitment supports the Partners’ intention that the operation of the Minnesota Power 
utility will continue to be handled by the existing management team.

Labor 
Protections  28.The Company will maintain the current senior management team, subject to
changes to account for voluntary departures or terminations in the ordinary course.Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  
Alley Rebuttal Sec. III. G. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. II. Minnesota Power currently has no regulatory requirement to maintain its current senior 
management team, and there is no guarantee a different investor/owner would make such a 
commitment.   
29.Minnesota Power  nonunion  employees will maintain the same or better position
and compensation and benefits for two years following the close of the transaction
and all existing collective bargaining agreements will be honored.Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  
Krollman Rebuttal Sec. II. A. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  Approval of the Acquisition further ensures the Company will be able to and will provide 
compensation and benefits to employees  at their current level  for at least two more years , 
providing important certainty to employees during a period of transition that allows Minnesota 
Power to continue to recruit and retain a talented workforce . 
30.Neither the Company nor the Partners intend to change Minnesota Power’s long -
standing practices with regards to contractors. For example, the Company routinely
contractually requires contractors and subcontractors to pay their workers
prevailing wage as ev idenced by local collective bargaining agreements and to
ascertain local conditions, work rules, and union jurisdiction. The Company also
seeks to deploy union labor wherever reasonably possible.Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  Approval of the Acquisition further ensures the Company will be able to and will maintain its 
long-standing practices with regard to contractors.

1 I.  INTRODUCTION 
LPI is an ad hoc consortium of Minnesota Power’s largest industrial customers.  LPI 
members are some of the largest industrial users of energy in the nation with the cost of energy 
being roughly 25%  of the overall cost of production.  LPI has a significant impact on the state’s 
economy, jobs, and taxes.  Collectively, during normal operations, LPI members contribute $5 
billion annually to the Minnesota economy, directly and indirectly support over 13,000 jobs  with 
a collective annual payroll of more than $400 million, and pay more than $150 million annually in 
State taxes.  Similarly, LPI members pay the majority of Minnesota Power’s required revenues.  
This economic engine  in Northern Minnesota also pays roughly two -thirds of Minnesota Power’s 
annual revenue.  It therefore has a keen interest in the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, the associated investment plan, and how that will impact utility rates.   
The purpose of this proceeding is to examine the proposed acquisition of all outstanding 
shares of ALLETE, Inc. (“ALLETE”), of  which  Minnesota Power (the “Company”)  is an 
operating division, by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”  or “CPP” ) and 
Global Infrastructure  Partners (“GIP”) (together, the “Partners ,” and with ALLETE, the 
“Petitioners” or “Applicants” ) (the “ Proposed Acquisition” or “Proposed Transaction” ) and to 
determine if the  Proposed Acquisition is in the public interest. 
The overarching request by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (the 
“Commission”) in the Order for Hearing was for the parties to engage in and develop a record 
pertaining to a cost -benefit analysis.  After weighing the potential harms with the potential 
benefits, as directed by the Commission, LPI  concludes that the Proposed Acquisition is not in the 
public interest and recommends the ALJ and  Commission reject it.  
The record shows that this case is fundamentally about two things.  First, a capital 
investment plan and second, obtaining financing for that capital investment plan.  ALLETE is 
selling to global investment firms to obtain financing for what can only be de scribed as a 
significantly outsized investment plan.  The testimony shows that this plan is roughly $1 billion per year over a 20- year timeframe, driven by Minnesota Power, or  $20 billion.  To put this in 
perspective, that equates to over $83 million per month over twenty years.  Spread across Minnesota Power’s 150,000 ratepayers, Minnesota Power is proposing to spend over $550 per 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION EXCISED
2 month, per ratepayer.  Incorporating a rate of return, it is difficult to imagine what ratepayers’ 
monthly bills will be in 15 -20 years.  To support this enormous capital investment, the testimony 
shows that ALLETE allegedly needs  more equity over the next five years than it has obtained in 
its 75 -year existence.  The testimony does not show this significant capital plan is consistent with 
the public interest or that Minnesota Power could not raise equity in public markets , as it has done 
for seventy -five years  at a much more reasonable pace.  
Instead, the testimony shows that the Partners see an opportunity to have exclusive access 
to provide that capital in exchange for generous returns on this outsized investment, and even 
greater returns if the Commission expedites these investments.  In fac t, the testimony shows that 
the Partners are so eager to have exclusive access that they are willing to commit, as of this filing , 
to fully fund ALLETE’s equity needs over the next five years.  This eagerness should raise red 
flags, not a welcome banquet.  
To be sure, the testimony shows this exclusive access comes at a significant cost and risk 
to ratepayers.  
• There is a cost in implicitly approving the outsized capital plan, which will cause 
Minnesota Power’s rates to skyrocket. 
• There is a risk that the Partners will sell ALLETE once they have realized their 
profits, or sooner if the Commission does not approve the irresponsible capital plan.  
• There is a risk that the Partners will act in their self -interest to directly influence 
and accelerate this capital investment to maximize returns  in the near term .  
• There is a risk that the Partners will seek to de -risk cost -recovery of that investment 
via various rate adjustment mechanisms.  
• There is a cost in Minnesota Power ceding control of its budgetary and strategic 
decisions to global investment firms.  
• There is a cost in the dilution of Minnesota Power as a core asset in ALLETE. 
• There is a risk that a privately owned company will be less transparent than a 
publicly traded company. 
• And from LPI’s perspective, there is the potential significant cost of ultimately 
bearing cost responsibility for over $12 billion (two-thirds) of the $20 billion capital plan, 
which would jeopardize LPI’s competitiveness.

3 ALLETE and the Partners have utterly failed to bear their burden of proof to demonstrate 
tangible benefits of the acquisition that outweigh these risks and costs.  The alleged concessions 
offered by Minnesota Power and the Partners amount to little more than restatements of existing 
obligations and do nothing to address the real and significant concerns raised in this proceeding.  
LPI therefore respectfully requests the ALJ protect Minnesotans and Minnesota businesses and recommend the Commission deny the Acquisition.

II.  SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND OF THE PROPOSED TRANSACTION 
A. ALLETE and the Partners  
ALLETE is a publicly traded utility company based in Duluth, Minnesota.  Minnesota 
Power is an operating division of ALLETE, also based in Duluth, that has the exclusive right to 
provide retail electric service in various geographic pockets of a 26,000- square- mile area of central 
and northern Minnesota.2  ALLETE’s other regulated operations include Superior Water, Light & 
Power, an electric, water, and gas utility in Wisconsin, and eight percent ownership in American 
Transmission Company, an independent transmission company in Wisconsin.3  Additionally, 
ALLETE is the corporate parent of BNI Energy, which owns and operates a lignite mine, BNI Coal, LTD, in North Dakota.
4  ALLETE also has investments in unregulated clean energy 
infrastructure through ALLETE Clean Energy and New Energy Equity.5   
CPP Investments is a professional investment management organization that manages the 
Canada Pension Plan Fund on behalf of more than 22 million Canadians.6  As of March 31, 2024, 
CPP Investments managed assets totaling  C$632.3 billion, with a United States investment 
portfolio of C$267.6 billion (approximately US$197.7 billion) invested directly and indirectly in equity and fixed income in public and private companies across a variety of sectors including in 
real estate, infrastructure, and energy.
7  CPP Investments’ purpose is to maximize the rate of return 
for its investments for the benefit of Canadians.8

Partners V (“GIP Fund V”) and Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P. (“Tower Bridge”).11  
GIP Fund V is managed by a GIP -controlled affiliate with several limited partners, while Tower 
Bridge Fund is a fund managed by a GIP -controlled affiliate, with the California Public 
Employees’ Retirement System (“CalPERS”) as the sole limited partner.12 
GIP was recently acquired by BlackRock, Inc. (“BlackRock”).13  Blackrock is a “publicly  
traded … investment management firm domiciled in the United States that provides investment management services to its mutual funds, investment accounts, and other investment funds.”
14  
Notably, while BlackRock currently owns approximately 13.2% of outstanding ALLETE shares,15 
it will, through GIP and the transaction, exercise far greater control over ALLETE than it currently 
does.   
B. The Proposed Acquisition  
On, July 19, 2024, ALLETE, GIP, and CPP Investments filed their Petition before the 
Commission seeking approval of the Proposed Acquisition.  According to the Petition, GIP and 
CPP Investments plan to form a new corporation, Alloy Parent LLC, to acquire all of ALLETE’s 
shares and interests.

9 C. Other Regulatory Approvals 
In addition to the approval the Applicants seek from the Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission, the Company also filed for approval from the Public Service Commission of 
Wisconsin  (“PSCW”) on July 19, 2024, in Docket No. 5820- DR-100, and from the Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission (“FERC”), on July 19, 2024, in Docket No. EC24-105.22  The PSCW 
approved ALLETE’s acquisition application in relation to Superior Water, Light and Power 
Company (“SWLP”)  on March 13, 2025, after parties to that proceeding waived their rights to a 
contested case. 23  Additionally, on December 19, 2024, FERC approved the  acquisition  
application but noted that “ whether the Proposed Transaction fulfills the respective state 
requirements for Minnesota Commission … approval is a separate question from whether the 
Proposed Transaction is consistent with the public interest under FPA section 203, and our findings 
under FPA section 203 do not  affect those agencies’ evaluation of the Proposed Transaction.”24 
D. Public Comments  
The Proposed Acquisition has generated significant public discourse, resulting in the filing 
of roughly 414 public comments  as of the date of this Initial Brief .  Of those comments, the 
overwhelming majority, approximately 379, express explicit opposition to the Proposed 
Transaction .  Among the approximately 30 supporting comments, a majority of the commenters 
work for ALLETE or Minnesota Power, and the comments largely express support for Minnesota Power’s leadership .  These supporting commenters generally overlook the incentive compensation 
ALLETE’s leaders will receive upon closing and that these same leaders are ceding control of all future strategic decisions of the Company.  Opposition comments focus in large part on the 
potential for the acquisition to have an outsized impact on ratepayers and cause significant rate 
increases, beyond what is tenable for local Minnesota Power customers.  Comments also highlight 
Minnesota Power’s noticeable absence of evidence to demonstrate that it struggles with access  to 
capital, and lack of concrete commitment to comply with the Carbon Free Standard or ensure clean 
energy is prioritized above profit.

10 III.  LEGAL STANDARD AND BURDEN OF PROOF  
A. Under Either Standard, whether a “Net Benefit” or “No Harm” Standard, the 
Proposed Transaction Is Not in the Public Interest.    
Under any standard  of review , the Proposed Transaction should be denied because it poses 
significant risk and no benefits .  The Applicants acknowledge that “the definition of public 
interest…is derived from the vast body of energy policy developed over many years in Minnesota 
and for each new matter before the Commission will depend on the then- applicable statutes and 
rules and  the circumstances of that matter.”25  Counsel for the Partners conceded during opening 
statement s that “the Commission’s authority in this area is vast and comprehensive and that the 
Commission is going to use that authority to find the right balance and protect customers.”26  Here, 
the burden of proof, and its application, are open issues for the Commission’s ultimate 
determination.27  
B. The Commission Has Discretion in Applying the Public Interest Standard Required 
by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 to Determine the Statute Requires a Showing of “Net 
Benefits” to Comport with  the Public Interest .  
When considering approval of the acquisition, merger, or consolidation of a public utility 
in Minnesota, Minn Stat. § 216B.50 requires the Commission find that “the proposed action is 
consistent with the public interest” before giving “its consent and appr oval.”28  However, the 
statute does not prescribe a specific method in which the Commission must analyze the public interest standard – thus, the Commission has discretion in how it applies statutory public interest

demonstration of net benefits.

D. A “Net Benefits” Standard Should Apply to The Proposed Transaction Based on the 
Significance of the Proposed Acquisition. 
Although the Commission does not have a brightline test under which to analyze whether 
a transaction comports with the public interest, the Commission has discretion to apply the 
mandate of Minn Stat. § 216B.50 in the way it sees fit.  The public interest standard in this case 
poses a different question – the Commission has not been asked to simply weigh the sale of a 
generation facility , or even the merger of two utilities .  Rather, the issue before the Commission 
appears to be a matter of first impression , and it is  tasked with determining whether the sale of one 
of the state’s most prominent public utilities to private investors, who have no accountability to 
Minnesota ratepayers, comports with the public interest.  The unique and weighty question posed 
by the distinct set of facts in this case warrants a showing that the Proposed Acquisition will not only not harm ratepayers, but will provide them a net benefit. 
The facts of each proposed transaction under this statute will differ, and the Commission 
will need to weigh diverse and unique factors when determining whether each proposed transaction 
comports with the public interest.  As stated above, at stake in this Proposed Acquisition is the

20 IV.  ANALYSIS  
A. There Is No Benefit to the Acquisition, Which Is Premised on a Need T hat Does Not , 
and Should Not,  Exist.   
The Proposed Acquisition poses no benefits to customers.  Minnesota Power admits that 
the Acquisition will not make its electricity safer, more reliable, or more affordable.57  Instead, the 
sole benefit they have touted is improved access to capital.58   
As an initial matter, the  Petitioners ’ continued emphasis of the alleged unfettered supply 
of capital from the Partners underscores that the Proposed Acquisition and the capital investment 
plan are one and the same – ALLETE would not have approached GIP and CPP without the alleged 
need for the capital investment plan and GIP and CPP would not be acquiring ALLETE but for the financial rewards associated with that  capital investment plan.  The Proposed Acquisition is 
premised on the fact that ALLETE needs to raise significant capital in the next five years, but this 
premise is flawed for at least two reasons .  First, the amount of capital the Company says it needs 
to raise is unprecedented in its history.  Investing that amount of capital, which must be recovered from customers, would cause extreme rate shock,

Institutional investors, such as pension funds, insurance companies, endowments, and 
sovereign wealth funds, are often considered forms of patient capital due to their  long- term 
investment horizons and willingness  to commit their funds to investments that may take years or 
decades to mature.100  This contrasts with more speculative or short -term investors who seek quick 
returns.  Institutional investors such as pension funds, insurance companies, and sovereign wealth 
funds tend to invest in utilities because of their predictable cash flows, stable dividends, and long-
term growth potential.101  These characteristics align well with the long -term goals of institutional 
investors to meet liabilities and obligations over decades, which makes their investments more patient by nature.  Institutional investors are less likely to react to short -term m arket fluctuations 
compared to individual retail investors.
102  Utilities, being regulated and relatively stable 
businesses, generally fit well within their portfolio strategies aimed at steady returns over time, 
reinforcing the concept of patient capital.  Access to patient capital is not a new or novel concept 
for ALLETE.  Again, almost 75% of its shares are currently owned by institutional investors.103

which only a very limited number of stakeholders were allowed to access , preventing meaningful

46 (often beyond that provided to the SEC), including financial projections, workforce projections, 
potential legal issues, etc.155  In contrast, private equity- owned companies are not subject to the 
same level of public reporting and do not provide detailed information about the acquiring firms’ other investments.  This is problematic for several reasons.  The reduction in reporting 
requirements means that critical information about the company’s performance, strategic decisions, and potential risks can be obscured from public view.
156  Consequently, regulators have 
less insight into the company’s operations and financial health, which undermines transparency and accountability.  Specifically, regulators have less ability to monitor the company’s decisions 
and hold management accountable for practices that could lead to inefficiencies or excessive profits at the expense of the public interest.
157 
In contrast to private equity, public ownership ensures accountability in ways that might 
be lost under private equity ownership.  Publicly traded companies, especially those in critical 
infrastructure sectors like utilities, are held accountable through a  combination of regulatory 
oversight, investor scrutiny, and public reporting.  These filings include various FERC reporting 
requirements, state agency reporting requirements, and SEC reporting requirements.158  Public 
ownership forces a company to regularly report performance metrics, engage with a diverse shareholder base, and face questions from regulatory bodies and the media.  This level of 
accountability helps ensure that decisions are made in the public interest.  Under private equity 
ownership, many of these layers of accountability are weakened or removed, leaving fewer checks 
and balances on potentially profit -driven decisions that will reduce transparency and could 
disadvantage ratepayers.
159  The ability for ratepayers to scrutinize the operation of their utility 
would be greatly reduced by a lack of transparency that comes with private equity ownership.

3. The Partners Will Seek to Maximize Their Return .  
The dilution of Minnesota Power as a “Core Division” of ALLETE is concerning.  
Generally speaking, private equity companies are investment firms that pool capital from 
institutional and high-net- worth investors to acquire equity ownership in private companies or 
publicly traded companies they intend to take private.  Their primary go al is to generate significant 
returns by improving the financial performance or strategic position of the companies they invest 
in.  These firms typically use a combination of investor equity and debt (leveraged buyouts, or 
LBOs) to finance acquisitions. 
Private equity is characterized by high illiquidity, requiring long- term commitments from 
its investors, and carries higher risks than seasoned public equity investments.  Private equity 
investments generally offer higher expected returns to compensate for  these increased risks, 
making them a potentially rewarding but demanding investment class.196  In this instance, based 
in part on the massive investment they intend to make to rate base, GIP has advertised that the GIP 
Fund V is targeting a 15-20% annual return.197   
The Partners are transparent about their intentions to maximize MP’s growth.  In their 
respective direct testimonies, both GIP and CPP make their intentions to maximize the return on 
their investment in MP, explaining that they are obligated to do so.  GIP states l ike any other 
investor, it “seeks to maximize the return on its investments and has an obligation to its investors 
to try to do so.”198  Similarly, CPP notes that private investments “ help CPP Investments fulfill its 
statutory mandate to maximize returns for the CPP …”199

are not bound to hold their interests in Alloy Parent for any particular period of time.  There is no limitation on the Partners’ ability to borrow the money to make equity infusions in ALLETE.

73 7. The Partners’ Control of the ALLETE Board and Their Investment and Exit 
Strategies  Threaten Compliance with the C arbon F ree Standard. 
In 2023, the Minnesota legislature enacted a Carbon Free Standard (“CFS”) which requires 
electric utilities to provide Minnesota customers with power that is 100 percent carbon free by 
2040.  Minnesota Power has established decarbonization goals, which its 2025- 2039 Integrated 
Resource Plan (“2025- 2039 IRP”) intends to facilitate, specifically by curating an annual energy 
portfolio resulting in 80 percent renewable energy by 2030, and 90 percent renewable energy by 
2035 (Docket No. E015/RP -25-127).272  Minnesota Power intends to add 400 MW of new wind 
projects by 2035 and expand energy storage resources by 100 MW by 2035.   
Despite its decarbonization goals, Minnesota Power’s  2025- 2039 IRP  proposes to add 
approximately 1,000 MW of natural gas capacity to replace baseload generation at Boswell Energy Center, on top of its existing natural gas generation .  Part of its plan accounts for  its share of the 
Nemadji Trail Energy Center (“NTEC”) , a natural gas plant being built in Superior , Wisconsin by 
Minnesota Power, Dairyland Power Cooperative, and Basin Electric Power Cooperative, the 
contracts for which remain in effect today.  While the Commission requests comment on 
Minnesota Power ’s ability to comply with the CFS in relation to any proposed modifications of 
plans associated with the NTEC, LPI unfortunately cannot provide detailed comment because the 
2025- 2039 IRP provides scant information on its intended treatment of NTEC.  In its 2025-2039 
IRP, Minnesota Power  states that although NTEC and associated contracts are still in effect, it did 
not include NTEC in its starting point Load and Capability Forecast, or its Capacity Expansion 
analysis, as it is restudying the need for natural gas generation in its 2025- 2039 IR P.
273  However,
