unexpected customer needs, it will develop 750 MW of combined cycle natural gas generation to 
be in service by 2035.”274  In pursuit of that goal, Minnesota Power  states, “[o]n receipt of final 
permits for the Nemadji Trail Energy Center (“NTEC”), and if available to meet IRP needs, the

Nevertheless, it is clear t he Partners’ control of the ALLETE Board of Directors, and their

coal operations, there is no guarantee that future owners would  follow through on current plans to 
retire Minnesota Power’s coal fleet.   The Commission should deny the Transaction, which would 
jeopardize compliance with the CFS, and every other aspect of service provided by Minnesota 
Power.

debt for  ratemaking purposes is determined using a utility’s embedded cost of debt, or the average 
interest rate on its outstanding bonds, weighted by the principal balances of  those bonds.  The 
embedded cost of debt therefore changes slowly, as new debt  issuances get averaged into the 
utility’s existing stock of debt.  Therefore, there is not a great potential for Minnesota Power’s 
embedded cost of debt to rise much in just thre e years , and the Partners’ commitment to hold 
customers harmless from a rise in the cost of debt is meaningless .

When El Paso Electric was acquired by Infrastructure Investment Fund (“IIF”) in 2020,  
both the parties’ stipulation and the Texas Commission’s Order required that El Paso  Electric have 
ten directors —two from IIF, the El Paso CEO, and the remaining seven independent as defined by 
the NYSE.  Of these seven independent directors, at least four  also had to be disinterested.  Clear 
Delegations of Authority echoing these provisions were attached to the stipulation in that case.  
The Texas Order adopted these provisions and required El Paso Electric to amend its bylaws to 
incorporate the  delegation of authorities and other commitments, and these governing documents 
cannot be changed without Commission approval.292  
In a similar vein, in 2023 the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities approved the acquisition 
of South Jersey Industries (SJI), parent of two natural gas utilities, by IIF based on the stipulation 
of the parties.  Both the  stipulation and the Order in that proceeding required governance provisions 
much like  those in the El Paso Electric transaction.   New Jersey and Texas regulators further 
protected the public utility and its  ratepayers by imposing certain voting protocols for specified 
material events.  For example, a majority of independent director votes is needed to place SJI in 
voluntary bankruptcy, and the majority of both IIF directors and independent directors is needed 
to approve certain budget variances for El Paso Electric.293  Overall, the agreed -upon governance

The Parties are unwilling to fully comply with the Commission’s affiliated interest statute, 
which is meant to ensure sufficient transparency around utility contracting to prevent potential 
conflicts of interest.  As part of its list of commitments included in Rebuttal Testimony, Minnesota 
Power will require all suppliers and any industrial customers with contracted rates to identify 
annually whether they are more than five percent owned by CPP, GIP, or Blackrock and will list 
those entities in its annual affiliated interest report.

Investments, or BlackRock .

Minnesota Power would require all suppliers and any industrial customers with contracted rates to identify annually whether they are more than five percent owned by CPP Investments, GIP, or 
BlackRock, and then report those entities on it s Annual Affiliated Interest Report.   Minnesota

83 While these ideas  may help with transparency and are a step in the right direction, they fall 
short of compliance with the statute.   If the ALLETE acquisition moves forward, Minnesota Power 
will be the only utility in the state that is 100% owned by private equity.  The situation in which a 
regulated utility will be owned by only two entities  – 60% by one and 40% by another  – is quite 
unique.  If Minnesota Power does not track its affiliates and submit its affiliated transactions as 
required, the work of th e Commission and the Department to ensure that ratepayers are being 
protected from self-dealing becomes extremely difficult , if not impossible.  To be sure, some 
transactions with affiliates can benefit ratepayers, but some may not.  Regulators should know 
about these transactions, so they can be more closely reviewed in a timely fashion, and that is what the statute is designed to do.
303 
Applicants Witness Lapson suggests that any risk of interference in the business affairs of 
ALLETE by its new owners is no more problematic than that of other regulated utilities.304  But 
there is no comparison to the instant Transaction.  None of the utility holding companies mentioned by Witness Lapson have two private owners with business interests in hundreds of other companies  
that may have conflicts with their utility.  They are also publicly owned, which offers additional 
transparency.
305 
The affiliated interested statute is in place as the mechanism for the Department and 
Commission to accomplish the monitoring of affiliated interest agreements and to protect 
ratepayers from self -dealing by a public utility.  There is no evidence  in the record that the 
Commission will be able to effectively monitor conflicts of interest.  Rather than assist the 
Commission in its obligation to protect ratepayers, the Petitioners’  proposal would hamper the 
Commission’s ability to do so because Minnesota Power  would not be filing all relevant 
agreements.306

84 V.  CONCLUSION 
As demonstrated above, there are significant concerns, and several potential harmful 
aspects that far outweigh any potential benefits of the Acquisition.  The lynchpin of the Proposed 
Acquisition  is the exorbitant increase in rate base that will drive investment returns, as evidenced 
by a record replete with projected increases in capital investments.  Yet the Applicants fail to 
explain how rate affordability will be achieved.  Minnesota Power’s  rates already fail to comply 
with the goals set out in Minn. Stat. § 216C.05, subd. 2(4) given that all rate classes are not below 95% of the national average rates.  Approving the Acquisition to meet the requirements of the 
Carbon Free Standard, without consideration of the impact on rates and without serious 
modifi cation, will potentially lead to an affordability crisis and put the Company in a dire situation.  
Such an outcome is inconsistent with the public interest.  LPI  recommend s the ALJ and 
Commission find the Proposed Acquisition is inconsistent with the publi c interest and reject it.

1 INTRODUCTION 
 The proposed $6.2 billion sale of ALLETE to Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) and 
Canadian Pension Plan Investment  Board  (“CPPIB”) (collectively, “Petitioners”) is inconsistent 
with the public interest standard .1 Petitioners have neither  established that their  deal, as proposed, 
will produce meaningful benefits,  nor have they refuted the foreseeable risks.  
The Commission cannot be certain the deal will finance ALLETE’s energy transition. T he 
final merger agreement  contains no binding capital commitment. Moreover, GIP and CPPIB 
(collectively, the “Partners”)  will only fund ALLETE’s energy transition if it maximizes near -term 
returns  better than many alternatives . As a result, equity financing for ALLETE’s transition  could 
disappear for a variety of plausible reasons. Even if the Partners do provide capital, the ir plan to 
use risky financial strategies could financially weaken  ALLETE. Their plan  also could leave 
customer  rates nearly [NOT PUBLIC HCTS DATA BEGINS . . .  . . . NOT PUBLIC 
HCTS DATA ENDS] by 2030.2  
Despite  the deal ’s risks  to ALLETE’s financial health, ratepayers, and the energy 
transition , Petitioners  have proposed inadequate  governance and ring-fencing measures. And  
Petitioners  have no plans  to comply with a state law intended to prevent conflicts of interest and 
cross subsidies between public utilities and other companies with the same owner.  
Given the speculative benefits and foreseeable risks, the Commission should reject the 
petition as currently proposed as inconsistent with the public interest.

2 FACTS  
Private Equity Firms  
 
 P rivate equity firms commonly raise capital from investors in commingled funds  with fixed 
lengths.3 Once a private equity firm has raised a fund, it will seek to invest substantially all the  
fund’s capital in companies  within four to five years , which become part of the fund’s portfolio .4 
Once the fund’s investment period ends, the firm will generally have little  ability to make new or 
follow-on investments in the fund’s portfolio companies.5  
Private equity firms typically seek to grow the portfolio company’s value during a four -to-
six-year hold period before selling it or taking it public through an initial public offering.6 Private 
equity firms typically seek returns that exceed  the stock market. Private equity firms focus on 
growing cash flows by increasing  portfolio company revenue, cutting costs, or acquiring 
competitors.7 Private equity firms often target gross investment returns of 15% to 20% per year.8  
To achieve above- market  returns, private equity firms often rely on “financial engineering” 
to generate investor returns .9 Financial engineering involves manipulating  the portfolio company’s 
capital structure .10 For example, private equity firms often engage in “dividend recapitalization” 
to add debt to their portfolio companies’ balance sheets and then use the proceeds to collect 
dividends for themselves.11 Additionally , private equity firms may “double leverage” the portfolio 
company by having a holding company issue debt and then reinvest that debt in the portfolio

3 company as equity.12 This arrangement imposes the debt financing costs on the portfolio company 
while depriving it of the tax advantages .13 Despite this arrangement, the portfolio company is 
almost always  responsible for paying back the debt, not the private equity firm.14 
In addition to financial engineering, private equity firms may engage in “govern ance 
engineering” or “operational engineering” to maximize returns. Governance engineering involves 
replacing management and restructuring compensation to align the  manager  incentives with 
investor interests.15 Operational engineering refers to actively managing the portfolio company by 
altering  business practices, such as  through cost -cutting , to increase revenue.16

ALLETE  
 
 ALLETE is a publicly traded company focused on energy and utility service. It was 
founded as the Duluth- Edison Electric Company in 1906. ALLETE changed its name several times 
before adopting its current name in 2001.40 ALLETE’s stock was first listed on the New York 
Stock Exchange in 1950.41 Since then, the company has always had reliable access to equity 
capital.42

Exchange ’s independence standards, governs the company.43 The New York Stock Exchange’s 
independence standards require that no “material relationship” exist between ALLETE and a 
director.44 A material relationship generally exists when:

ARGUMENT  
 Petitioners have not establish ed by a preponderance of the evidence that their proposed 
deal is consistent with the public interest.115 To determine whether  a transaction is consistent with 
the public interest, perceived detriments must be weighed against perceived benefits to the 
public.116 In applying this balancing test, the Commission considers whether  it is reasonably likely 
that a transaction will either benefit or harm ratepayers .117 The Commission approves transactions 
when the “benefits are sufficient to justify the proposal.”118 The Commission likewise reject s 
transactions where the “potential costs to ratepayers are too high, and the potential benefits too 
uncertain.”119  
Under this balancing test, Petitioners’ proposed deal is in consistent with the public interest. 
In terms of benefits, Petitioners assert that their deal  ensures ALLETE has access to needed equity 
capital. But t he record shows that the proposed deal may impair  instead of improve access  to 
capital . The other identified  benefit  of the deal, access to expertise, lacks value given the  Partners’  
public assurances that they intend to maintain ALLETE’s existing management. On the other side

financial health, and ratepayers . On balance, the risks of the deal , as proposed, outweigh the 
possible benefits. And the regulatory commitments offered by Petitioners are inadequate to 
outweigh the deal’s  net harm. Because the deal as proposed is inconsistent with the public interest, 
the Commission should reject it.  
I.  P ETITIONERS HAVE FAILED TO ESTABLISH THEIR  DEAL  IS BENEFICIAL . 
 Petitioners  assert their deal’s  primary goal is improving access to equity capital  for 
ALLETE’s  energy transition.120 Despite this assertion, Petitioners have offered  little evidence that 
ALLETE’s stated capital needs are accurate and, even if they are, that the deal will more reliably 
meet those needs than the public market. R ecord evidence instead establish es that ALLETE’s 
capital needs ar e likely overstated  and that the public market may  better meet its  needs. The 
secondary benefit,  access to expertise, has little value.  
A. The Record Establishes T hat the  Deal’s  Primary Purpose Was Not Secur ing 
Capital Access.  
 ALLETE claim s that this deal  is essential to secure reliable access to equity capital and 
that continued public market reliance would leave it in a financially untenable position.121 Yet, as 
recently as March 2024, ALLETE was prepared to proceed with its “ standalone plan,” relying on 
the public capital market, a renewed focus on regulated operations, and more realistic equity needs 
to achieve its energy transition. The terms of the merger agreement similarly show that access to 
capital was not the deal’s most primary  goal. 
ALLETE repeatedly rejected offers from the only bidders , risking that it would be left with 
its standalone plan. [NOT PUBLIC HCTS DATA BEGINS . . .

 ALLETE further asserts that market inefficiencies can cause a publicly traded stock to be 
“mispriced by the public market for noticeable periods of time for no discernable reason based on

broad stock market moves affecting most publicly traded stocks , and (c) significant emergency 
events.149 According to ALLETE, a company can be “inconvenienced” if it needs to raise equity 
during a mispricing event, as it “may have no choice but to issue shares at a disadvantageous price, potentially raising less capital than needed.”
150 ALLETE’s concerns about mispricing events lack 
support.  Single- company events are unlikely to prevent ALLETE from accessing capital. Sound 
financial theory establishes that a stock’s price usually  reflects equity valuation  fundamental s over 
the long run.

24 fundamentals than on reported earnings.152 Market evidence further establishes that no significant 
gap exists between a company’s value and its stock market value, or that any gap can be explained 
by a company’s historical performance relative to its peers or by the way the market is valuing an  
entire industry.153 If the public market was highly inefficient, investors would buy the affected 
stocks when their prices dipped, earning excess returns as the stock prices rebounded. But investors 
rarely earn returns exceeding passive market benchmarks . Most active investors underperform the 
market. A S&P Global study, for example, found that more than 90% of actively managed U.S. 
equity funds have underperformed a passively managed benchmark during both the past ten years 
and the past three years.154 
 Becoming a private company will not help ALLETE access capital during a broad market 
downturn. Privately held companies may even have less access to capital during broad market downturns than publicly traded ones.
155 Capital typically flows  into investments that provide the 
highest expected risk -adjusted returns.156 If a broad market move downward, such as during a 
recession , temporarily discounts publicly traded company equity, investors with capital available 
would likely prefer to invest in those discounted companies  over alternatives .157 Privately held 
companies whose equity is not discounted in the same way, by contrast, would not be as attractive an investment.

25  Finally, emergency events like the COVID -19 pandemic’s onset  could make it difficult for 
both public and privately owned companies to access  equity.159 Companies guard against these 
types of events with credit facilities.160 Companies pay significant fees and premiums to banks for 
the right to force the banks to provide cash on demand.161 If a company w as planning a stock sale 
when such an event occurred, its credit facility should provide enough temporary liquidity to delay 
the sale until the capital markets recover.162 If a significant emergency event persisted, then capital 
expenditure plans would need to be reevaluated anyway .163 
C. Access to Expertise I s Not a Meaningful  Benefit . 
 Petitioners state  that access to the Partners’ deep utility and energy industry expertise will 
benefit ALLETE, even as they  have no plans to use this expertise .164 The Partner s also state that 
they will maintain  ALLETE’s  existing management  post- transaction. As a result,  ALLETE’s  
leadership will likely be the same either as a privately held or publicly traded company. Given 
these statements, t his potential benefit is not meaningful. The Commission should put little weight 
on it.165 
 In sum, ALLETE has not established its asserted capital needs or that the public market 
cannot adequately meet them. ALLETE’s claims conflict with the record and accepted financial theory. And the asserted benefits arising from the Partners’ expertise provides little value given Petitioners’ other representations.

26 II.  T HE PROPOSED DEAL  WILL EXPOSE THE ENERGY TRANSITION , ALLETE,  AND 
RATEPAYERS TO HARM . 
The Partners’ private messages  to internal committees and would -be investors establish 
significant risks. GIP and CPPIB  have no obligation to fund ALLETE’s 2040 energy transition. 
Even if the Partners do finance the transition, GIP and CPP IB will engage in risky private equity 
tactics  to achieve higher returns than available to  public investors.  
A. The Partners W ill Only F inance ALLETE’s 2040 E nergy Transition If It Is 
the Most Profitable Alternative.  
Petitioners assert this deal will ensure funding for clean energy projects needed to serve 
ALLETE’s rate -regulated customers. The record does not support  that claim. The Partners may 
deploy their capital to pursue significant natural gas investments or non- regulated projects. And 
even absent adverse economic conditions, the Partners may decide, consistent with their own 
investor obligations, that other investments offer a superior risk- adjusted return. The Partners also 
may lack capital for ALLETE, or the P artners may decide that delaying or maintaining fossil fuel 
infrastructure offers a better return.  The proposed deal does not adequately address these risks.  
While ALLETE suggests the deal will finance projects needed for its energy transition, 
Petitioners’ actions suggest they have other plans. Rather than decarbonizing, ALLETE’s recently filed integrated resource plan does not close the Boswell Energy Center, a fossil fuel power plant, and includes more than 1,000 MW of new natural gas capacity.

34 C. T
he Partners’ Current Plans  Will Weaken ALLETE’s Financial Health and
Lead to Increased  Customer Bills.
If the Partners use risky strategies to inflate their returns, ALLETE and ratepayers  will 
ultimately pay the associated bill. Excessive indebtedness w ould leave ALLETE in a financially 
brittle state: less able to make needed investments , less  resilient in a recession , and unable to 
maintain its credit ratings . Customers could experience higher rates and worse service.  
1. The Partners’ Planned Financial Engineering Will Harm ALLETE’s
Financial Health .
The Partners’ use of dividend recapitalization and double leveraging will ultimately 
undermine ALLETE’s credit metrics as the utility’s cash flows are diverted to service debt. I n a 
recession or other adverse economic event, the consequences for ALLETE – now lacking financial 
wiggle room – could be significant. 
The Commission should be concerned about Alloy Parent ’s debt outside of ALLETE’s 
regulated capital structure. Alloy Parent will own no assets or investments other than ALLETE. 
As a result, ALLETE will ultimately pay interest and principal payments on Alloy Parent ’s and 
ALLETE’s  debt.203 ALLETE’s regulated operations in Minnesota, which currently represent 
roughly 70% of the company, will ultimately be responsible for servicing most of this debt . If the 
incremental debt load becomes too large, or interest rates rise such that Alloy Parent or ALLETE have trouble refinancing the extra debt when it expires, Alloy Parent may try to extract cash from ALLETE to pay the incremental debt.
204 
While the Partners would be limited in how they could extract cash from ALLETE, they 
could direct ALLETE to  incrementally  increase debt within  its regulated capital structure, cut

as a credit risk . S&P Global Rating s, for example, considers whether owners and affiliates are

III. P ETITIONERS ’ PROPOSED GOVERNANCE PLAN AND LIMITED RING-FENCING 
COMMITMENTS ARE INCOMPATIBLE WITH THE PUBLIC INTEREST .  
 Given the deal could foreseeably produce net harm, Petitioners have offered various 
governance, affiliated interest, and ring- fencing commitments to rebalance the transaction in favor 
of approval. T hese proposed commitments are not currently sufficient. The governance plan is out -
of-step with other recent take -private transactions, and does not adequately balance investor, 
ratepayer, and community interests . The planned approach around affiliated interests does not

recent utility acquisitions and  are inadequate to protect rate- regulated customers from non-
regulated activities.

B. Petitioners  Have No  Plans to Comply with Minnesota’s A ffiliated -Interest 
Law. 
 Despite the plain language of Minnesota’s affiliated- interest statute, Petitioners propose 
only to report contracts with affiliate s that exceed $1 million  based on vendor self -reporting.237 
Even if this approach complied with state law, it would be inadequate to prevent conflicts of interest and cross subsidies between ALLETE and the Partners’ other portfolio companies.  State law provides that any person or corporation directly or indirectly holding at least 5% 
of the voting securities of a public utility is an affiliated interest. If that person or corporation also holds at least 5% of the voting securities of another c orporation, then an affiliated interest exists 
between th at corporation and the public utility too.
238 When an affiliated interest exists, no contract 
or arrangement involving more than $50,000 is valid or effective until the  contract or arrangement 
has received written Commission approval.239 The statute’s purpose is ensuring, in the absence of

43 C. Petitioners’  Proposed Ring-Fencing Provisions A re Inadequate to Protect 
Ratepayers.  
 Attempting  to rebalance benefits and harms, Petitioners propose various ring- fencing 
measures that purport to protect the regulated utility from risks posed by parent or affiliate entities. 
While these provisions are largely reasonable, they are not sufficient  to protect  ALLETE’s 
regulated operations.  
Ring- fencing creates a virtual barrier that segregates a portion of a company’s financial 
assets from the rest. Ring -fencing measures  can insulate a regulated utility from the potentially 
riskier activities of both its unregulated affiliate s and parent entities .245 While the proposed 
measures to protect ALLETE from parent entity activities  are generally consistent with those 
buyers have  offered  in other take -private transactions, the  proposed measures  omit key protections 
offered in other transactions. For example, the Partners  have not committed to obtaining a non-
consolidation legal opinion. A non- consolidation opinion would help prove that  ALLETE’s assets 
would be protected in the event of a parent or affiliate bankruptcy. Although she discounts the value in this proceeding,
246 Petitioner witness Ms. Lapson previously testified  that a  commitment 
to obtaining a  non- consolidation opinion was one of “the most important aspects” of the proposed 
protective measures in a take- private transaction .247 She explained that the commitment assured  
regulators that “an independent legal authority” would verify that proposed protections were 
properly implemented, and also “provide [d] greater comfort to current and prospective lenders and 
rating agencies.”248

44 Petitioners also have not addressed  the lack of adequate ring-fencing protections between 
ALLETE’s regulated and unregulated activities.249 While risks stemming from ALLETE’s 
unregulated operations exist today, the potential for unregulated investments to surge post -
transaction heightens those risks. A s those risks increase, ALLETE’s retail customers  would pay 
higher rates arising from increased utility debt costs.250 
In sum, the governance, affiliated interest, and ring- fencing commitments  currently 
proposed by Petitioners are inadequate to balance out the deal’s foreseeable net harm.  
  CONCLUSION 
 Petitioners’ deal, as proposed, will not provide ALLETE reliable capital access . The 
Partners’ private messages and memoranda establish that this deal presents far more risk than 
Petitioners publicly acknowledge. Approving this deal will  jeopardize ALLETE’s 2040 energy 
transition , the company’s long- term financial health, and the quality and affordability of retail 
service. Given the balance of benefits and harm, the deal is not consistent with the public interest. The Commission should not approve it as currently proposed.  Dated:  May 1, 2025 Respectfully submitted,

1 INTRODUCTION 
This case presents something unique in Minnesota’s history: a consortium of private equity 
investors proposing to acquire a publicly traded utility company.  That company, Duluth- based 
Minnesota Power, would have the Commission believe that the proposed acquisition won’t change 
the way Minnesota Power does business, its commitments to its employees, or the Commission’s oversight.  But private equity  investors don’t pay $3.9 billion and expect to get nothing in return.  
Rather, the record in this case demonstrates that Minnesota Power’s prospective acquirers plan to achieve the outsized returns th at characterize private equity by controlling the board of directors , 
raising rates, taking on debt, and reselling Minnesota Power at a profit.   
Minnesota law recognizes that well -functioning utilities  and affordable rates  are a public 
good and requires the Commission to review acquisitions  like this  to ensure that they are consistent 
with the public interest.  The  prospective acquirers’ plans hold risks for Minnesota Power’s 
ratepayers, the energy transition, and effective Commission oversight of the utility.  And, while the acquisition would greatly benefit ALLETE ’s shareholders and executives, the potential public 
benefits of a sale appear  marginal or illusory.  The ALJ and the Commission should find that the 
risk of giving over control of Minnesota Power to private interests outweighs any potential benefit, and that the proposed acquisition is therefore not consistent with the public inter est.

Upon outreach by J.P. Morgan, GIP , CPP,  and four other parties expressed interest in

the parties  other than GIP and CPP  had dropped out of the process because they could not offer

At this point, GIP and CPP were not yet working together as partners because J.P. Morgan 
was carefully controlling the confidentiality of the process ; it would not introduce the  two investors  
until late December.26   
On September 7 , GIP submitted a nonbinding offer of $71 per share, indicating that  it could 
fund at least 50  percent itself  but would likely need to partner with other investors to fully fund 
the purchase.27  A few days later , CPP submitted a nonbinding offer of $69.26 per share.28   
Following their initial offers, GIP and CPP continued to conduct due -diligence efforts with 
the assistance of ALLETE’s management.29  In October, ALLETE set a December deadline  for 
the prospective buyers  to submit binding proposals, but later pushed the deadline back to January 
2024 after b oth GIP and CPP requested more time to facilitate “equity consortium partnering 
discussions” with other investors.30   
On Nov ember 1,  Minnesota P ower  filed a rate case seeking $90 million in new annual 
revenue, a 12 percent net increase over then -current rates .31

VIII.  THE PARTNERS ’ PLANS FOR ALLETE  ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE INVESTMENT 
STRATEGIES OF PRIVATE EQUITY INVESTORS IN GENERAL . 
Like typical  private equity investors, the Partners do not seek to passively invest in target 
companies.  Instead, t he Partners’ stated plans for ALLETE reflect  common private equity 
strategies, including governance control, the use of debt to boost returns, and strategic sales. 
A. Private Equity  Investors Generally  Seek to Acquire Controlling Interests that 
Give Them  Influence  Over a Target’s Operations and Finances with the Goal 
of Maximizing Their Return Upon Exit.  
Private equity firms are investment managers that raise capital , typically from institutional 
investors such as sovereign wealth funds, pension funds, insurance companies, endowments, and 
wealthy individuals, and then use that capital, often along with substantial amounts of debt, to acquire companies or other assets .
72  Private equity investors, commonly referred to as “limited 
partners,” invest by contributing capital to funds established by private equity firms.73  While 
limited partners provide most of the capital, it is the “general partner” —an entity controlled, 
owned, or managed by the private equity firm —that selects a fund’s investments.74  In this case, 
GIP and CPP plan to share control of Alloy Holdings GP LLC, the general partner of the Alloy 
group of companies.75 
Successful private equity investing relies on careful evaluation of investments, structuring 
of deals, financial engineering , and operational engineering.76   Unlike investors in public

14 companies, private equity firms use their position as the controlling shareholder to make 
significant changes  to the companies they invest in, such as changes to the board of directors, 
changes to strategy, changes in spending, and changes to a business’s capital structure.77  Changes 
to capital structure include strategically increasing the amount of debt, or “leverage,” within a business or its corporate hierarchy to drive higher  returns.
78  The downside of leverage, however, 
is that the interest and principal repayment schedules can put pressure on management to cut expenses while weaking a company’s credit rating.
79  In extreme cases, overleveraging can result 
in a company’s liquidation or reorganization through bankruptcy.80 
Another key difference between public and private equity investors involves exit 
strategies.81  An exit strategy is a plan for ending involvement with a particular investment.82  For 
public investors, a typical exit strategy is simply to sell their shares through the same public market where they originally purchased the shares at a time when they feel the shares are fully valued.
83  
Private equity  exit strategies are often more specific regarding timing; many private equity funds 
have a pre- planned lifespan after which the general partner will sell the fund’s investments with 
the goal of maximizing the return for the limited partners.84   
Private equity  exit strategies include selling to (1) a “strategic” buyer who would integrate 
a new acquisition into its existing operations; (2) a “financial” buyer, such as another private equity 
fund or a hedge fund; or  (3) public investors through an initial public stock offering, or “IPO.”85

15 Each exit strategy has its pros and cons.  A strategic buyer can help a company open up an 
expanded customer base; on the downside, however, this type of  acquisition can lead to culture 
clashes or layoffs.86  A financial buyer can  bring dealmaking experience but, on the downside, 
may emphasize aggressive performance targets and introduce excessive leverage.87  Finally, an 
IPO allows access to vast pools of capital but tends to be an expensive process and leads to 
increased disclosures and scrutiny.88 
B. The Partners ’ Plan s for ALLETE  Include  Taking on  Debt, Us ing Control of 
ALLETE’s Board to Increase the Company’s Value, and Ultimately to Exit by 
Selling ALLETE for a Profit . 
Most  of the strategies used by private equity investors in general, such as increasing sales, 
cutting expenses, adding leverage, and exercising board control, c an also be appl ied to a privately 
owned utility.89  The  Partners plan to use typical private equity strategies if they are allowed to 
acquire ALLETE. 
Like private equity investors generally, the Partners plan  to use significant amounts of debt.

THE LEGAL STANDARD 
Under Minnesota Statutes section 216B.50, the Commission may not approve a public-
utility merger or acquisition unless it finds  that the transaction is consistent with the public 
interest.109  It is a petitioner’s burden to establish that a proposed transaction is consistent with the 
public interest by a preponderance of the evidence.110   
In evaluating whether a proposed transaction is consistent with the public interest, the 
Commission considers its  potential benefits and potential harms , well as whether any harms can 
be mitigated .111  The Commission will reject a transaction if the “potential costs to ratepayers are 
too high, and the potential benefits too uncertain.”112   
Consistent with these precedents , the Commission has asked the parties to address , among 
other things: 
• Whether there are any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed 
acquisition, including in relation to cost or risk;

20 • Whether there are any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public

• Whether the proposed acquisition is consistent with the public interest,

• Whether regulatory requirements or commitments are necessary to render the 
proposed acquisition consistent with the public interest.113 
ARGUMENT  
The proposed acquisition is not consistent with  the public interest because the potential 
harm s outweigh the potential benefits.  First, the acquisition would expose ratepayers to the risk 
that rates would increase unsustainably, as well as the risk that Minnesota Power’s service quality 
could be impaired in the long run.  Second, the acquisition poses risks to the energy transition due to uncertainties about the Partners’ future priorities.  Third, the acquisition would impair  regulatory 
oversight by giving control of ALLETE to new owners, reducing transparency, and making regulati ng affiliated interests more difficult.  Finally, the potential benefits of the proposed 
acquisition are marginal and insufficient to offset its many risks.  
I. T
HE PROPOSED ACQUISITION HOLDS RISKS FOR RATEPAYER S. 
The proposed acquisition holds substantial risks for ratepayers.  First, the rate increases on 
which the transaction is premised are unsustainable.  Second, the Partners plan to increase the amount of debt in ALLETE’s corporate hierarchy, which will intensify the risk of rate increases because it will tend to increase ALLETE and Minnesota Power’s borrowing costs.  Third , the cost -
cutting and use of leverage that is prevalent among  private equity investors, as well as ALLETE’s 
dependence on two investors, creates risks that its service quality may suffer over the long term.

21 A. The Proposed Acquisition Would Increase the Risk of Un affordabl e Rate 
Hikes.   
If approved , GIP and CPP’s proposal to acquire ALLETE would magnify the risk that 
Minnesota Power’s rates will rise at an unsustainable rate.   First, by negotiating for a substantial 
premium over ALLETE’s market price, ALLETE materially increased Partners’ incentive to raise  
rates.  Second, the record contains indications of Partners’ intent to do just that. 
In negotiating the deal, ALLETE insisted on receiving a substantial premium to its market 
value, rejecting an initial offer of $62.50 per share and a second offer of $64 per share before 
accepting a third offer of $67 per share .114  The last  price reflect s a premium of $1.5 billion over 
ALLETE’s book value .115  This premium  materially increases the risk of unsustainable rate hike s 
in the future  because the Partners w ould be incentivized to seek increases to  Minnesota Power’s 
ROE and/or grow its rate base substantially  to rec oup the premium.116   
While  Minnesota Power has stated that it will not attempt to recover the acquisition 
premium from utility customers ,117 this appears to simply be an assurance that the utility  will not  
include the premium as a line item in a future rate case.   This commitment does not fully  mitigate 
the risk  of substantial future rate increases motivated by the acquisition premium.118    
If the acquisition goes through, t he Partners w ill have the means  to influence Minnesota 
Power’s rate -case strategy  through their  control of ALLETE’s board.  According to one version of

C. The Proposed A cquisition Hold s Risks for S ervice Quality. 
The Partners’ proposed acquisition of ALLETE creates risks to Minnesota Power’s service 
quality in three ways.  First, the cost -cutting that private equity investors use to boost their returns 
poses a risk to reliable service over the long term.  Second, Partners’ planned use of debt to finance 
capital infusions materially increases the risk that ALLETE will experience financial distress or cash-flow problems in the future.  And, finally, ALLETE’s dependence on just two sources of 
capital, GIP and CPP, mean s that the Partners could decide that their money is better spent 
elsewhere, leaving ALLETE without access to equity capital . 
Private equity investors engage in operational engineering to increase revenue and

II. THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION HOLDS RISKS FOR THE ENERGY TRANSITION . 
A stated purpose of the proposed acquisition is to provide Minnesota Power with  access to 
capital that will help it execute the energy trans ition.155  Paradoxically, because of risks related to 
the Partners’  priorities and  potential exit strategy , the acquisition may end up impairing Minnesota 
Power’s ability to comply with Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard (CFS).   
The CFS requires an electric utility to generate or procure 100 percent of its sales to 
Minnesota retail customers from carbon -free energy technologies by 2040.156  The statute also sets 
intermediate goals of 80 percent by 2030 and 90 percent by 2035.157  Minnesota Power currently 
plans to meet these goals in part by ceasing coal-fired  generation at Boswell Energy Center Unit  3 
by December 31, 2029, and at Boswell Unit 4 by 2035.158

III. THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION THREATENS EFFECTIVE  REGULATORY OVERSIGHT . 
The Petitioners argue that the proposed acquisition would not change the Commission’s 
authority over Minnesota Power .177  But t here are at least three ways in which the acquisition  
would threaten effective regulatory oversight if approved.  First, effective regulation depends to a large degree on the cooperation of utilities.  In a change -of-control acquisition like this one, it 
matters who the acquirer is, and there are indications that the Partners could prove to be less- than
-
cooperative owners.  Second, the acquisition threatens effective regulation through the loss of the comprehensive reporting regime imposed on publicly traded companies by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.  F inally, the Partners’ extensive holdings  would make policing conflicts 
of interest much more difficult for the Commission and other stakeholders. 
A. Minnesota Power, Under the Partners ’ Control,  Would Be Less Transparent 
and Likely Less Cooperative, Impeding Effective Oversight .

the public interest because Minnesota Power would remain subject to Commission oversight and

The Partners’ control of ALLETE would allow them to shape regulation.  Sierra Club 
witness Lane used  the example of an IRP proceeding to illustrate how a utility  sets the information 
frame for Commission decisions.  If the IRP that a utility presents to the Commission is biased 
toward capital investments over operating expenses , “the Commission can try to mitigate this bias 
by disallowing certain aspects of the IRP, but it cannot craft a new resource plan without utility 
cooperation.”186  Similarly, while other parties can review and comment on a utility’s IRP 
proposal, the utility will always have the most technical knowledge and information, a 
phenomenon known as “information asymmetry.”187  In sum, although the Commission has 
authority to approve, reject or modify IRPs, it faces a disadvantage in trying to vet the prudence 
of a utility’s investment decisions.188 
The proposed acquisition  would not change the Commission’s authority  over Minnesota 
Power, but as the foregoing discussion demonstrates, this is  largely  beside the point.  The ease of 
regulating a utility is highly dependent on its  willingness to cooperate and work collaboratively 
with the Commission and other stakeholders.  And some of the litigation tactics employed in this 
proceeding suggest that the ease of regulating ALLETE could be adversely affected by the 
acquisition .

35 C. The Proposed A cquisition Would Make It More D ifficult to P olice Self-
Dealing. 
Policing self -dealing between utilities and their affiliates is an important purpose of 
regulation.  When utilities procure products or services, they have  a natural incentive to award 
contracts to affiliate d businesses  even if alternative providers  would be more competitive.  This 
type of self -dealing can result in a utility pass ing along above -market costs to ratepayers .202  Since 
utility  customers  cannot “take their business elsewhere” if self -dealing drives up their rates, they 
rely on the Commission to review  affiliated -interest agreements for reasonableness under 
Minnesota Statutes  section  216B.48. 
If the Commission approves the proposed acquisition, ALLETE will become affiliated with 
the vast network of companies contained in the Partners’ portfolios.203  GIP manages more than 
$100 billion in assets worldwide, while CPP manages nearly $200 billion in assets in the United 
States alone.204  GIP, moreover, is a wholly owned subsidiary of BlackRock, which manages over 
$11 trillion in assets worldwide.205  The existence of  hundreds if not thousands of new affiliates  
would magnify the risk that above -market costs will be passed on to ratepayers because of  
contracts that are not negotiated at arm’s length.206  While the Commission would have oversight 
of these transactions, the proposed acquisition will make this oversight more difficult for two 
reasons.  The first reason is the sheer number of opportunities that will exist for self -dealing .  The 
second is Partners’ lack of commitment to report self -dealing contracts as required by statute.  
First, although it is unknown how many contracts  ALLETE or Minnesota Power might 
make in the future  with BlackRock, GIP, or CPP affiliates, the opportunities would be many due

other recent take- private transactions ,” in which utilities or their acquirers had “made firm 
commitments to comply with affiliated interest statutes, rules, and regulations .”219  ALLETE and 
the Partners ’ failure  to simply commit to comply with t he law, as utilities in similar situations have 
done, ought to give the Commission pause .  This failure likely means one of two things: i t either 
(1) tells the Commission  about the degree of cooperation the Partners are likely to exhibit post -
acquisition or (2) demonstrates that Partners’ affiliates are so numerous that regulating their 
relations with Minnesota Power in accordance with Minnesota law is infeasible.  Regardless, it is neither advisable nor consistent  with the law for the Commission to accept  a commitment that 
amounts to less than full compl iance with the affiliated -interest statute .  
IV. T
HE PROPOSED ACQUISITION ’S BENEFITS ARE MARGINAL OR ILLUSORY . 
In contrast to the many serious risks posed by the acquisition, its potential benefits are 
limited.   The premise for  the acquisition is to provide ALLETE and Minnesota Power improved 
access to capital .  But it is far from clear that the acquisition would improve ALLETE’s access to 
capital .  ALLETE currently trades on the New York Stock Exchange, where it has access to vast 
pools of capital.  Moreover, the Petitioners’ claim that the  public market is inadequate is  based on 
the size of ALLETE’s capital need, but there are multiple avenues to mitigate that need.  Third,

only substantial ratepayer concession Partners make is to commit to provid e up to $3.5 million to 
forgive certain low -income -customer arrearages.271  Arrearage forgiveness  would certainly benefit 
the low -income households who receive it.  However, the public interest applies to all customers, 
not just low -income customers.272  And t o the extent that the transaction results in higher rates, it 
will harm all customers, including low -income customers who receive arrearage forgiveness.273  
Those future rate increases would put additional pressure on customer bills and  may cause  
increased arrearages.  
D. Many of the Petitioners’ Commitments  Simply Affirm that Minnesota Power 
Will Comply with the Law or Maintain the Status Quo . 
The Petitioners have provided a schedule memorializing various commitments pertaining 
to the post -acquisition behavior of ALLETE.274  The schedule , attached to the rebuttal testimony 
of Jennifer Cady, memorializ es 48 commitments and affirmations, including some commitments 
that were originally made in the merger agreement , the petition , or the Petitioners’ direct testimony 
and others that are new as of rebuttal .275  Despite the claimed number of commitments , their value  
to ratepayers and the community is  nominal at best.276  
Many of the Petitioners’ commitments are not affirmative benefits but rather reflect an 
effort  to mitigate the risks of the acquisition by promising to maintain the status quo.277  For

48 example, among the commitments classified as “Workforce and Labor Protections,” ALLETE 
commits to “ maintain the current senior management team ” and allow nonunion employees “the 
same or better position and compensation and benefits for two years ” while  disclaiming any intent 
to “change Minnesota Power’s longstanding practices with regards to contractors ” such as 
requiring contractors to pay their workers the prevailing wage.278  These commitments simply 
maintain the status quo; they do not provide any new benefits to ratepayers or the public interest.279 
Still other commitments, many of which Petitioners  label  as “affirmations,”280 simply state 
an intent to act consistent with law or existing regulatory practice.  For example, Commitment 36 
is a statement of regulatory fact: “rate recovery and allocation of rate recovery of Minnesota Power 
capital investments across customer classes are subject to [ Commission ] authority.”281  
Commitment 37 states that “ALLETE’s capital structure will be maintained within the range approved by the Commission in the annual capital structure filing, and Minnesota Power will continue its efforts to manage its capital structure to the level approved in its most recent Minnesota rate case. ”
282  This commitment simply affirms that the Commission has authority over ALLETE’s 
capital structure , that ALLETE is required to comply with the Commission’s capital- structure 
orders , and that ALLETE will continue to attempt to do so .283 
The record contains no indication that, before the Partners proposed to acquire ALLETE, 
there w ere any discussions of firing senior management, reducing employees’ compensation or

49 benefits, or paying contractors wages  that are below the prevailing rate.284  Nor was there any 
question that Minnesota Power would continue to be subject to the Commission’s jurisdiction or 
follow existing regulatory practices.  The commitments offered to address these possibilities need to be understood as just that : attempts to mitigate potential harms of the acquisition, not affirmative 
benefits to ratepayers or the public.  
CONCLUSION 
Fundamentally, this case is about assessing  whether the potential harms of the proposed 
acquisition of ALLETE outweigh the potential benefits.  As discussed above, the acquisition poses numerous, serious risks for ratepayers, the energy transition, and the Commission’s oversight of 
Minnesota Power.  It offers few benefits to anyone other than ALLETE’s shareholders.  Accordingly, the ALJ and the Commission should find that the risk of giving over control of Minnesota Power to private interests outweighs the potential benefits  and deem  the proposed 
acquisition inconsistent with the public interest.

employment
 
differ
 
among
 
the
 
PE
 
groups
 
that
 
sponsor
 
buyouts,
 
and
 
these
 
differences
 
persist
 
over
 
time
 
at
 
the
 
group
 
level.”
 
Davis,
 
Steven,
 
et
 
al.,

Economic
 
Effects
 
of
 
Private
 
Equity
 
Buyouts,
 
July
 
8,
 
2021,
 
https://ssrn.com/abstract=3465723
 
 
 
7
 
Ex.
 
CURE-600
 
(Baker
 
Direct)
 
at
 
7
 
model.
12
 
Finally,
 
Ms.
 
Bryant
 
observes
 
that
 
ownership
 
by
 
private
 
infrastructure
 
investors
 
could
 
align
 
better
 
with
 
the
 
long-term
 
interests
 
of
 
the
 
state
 
for
 
the
 
same
 
reason
 
many
 
affiliated
 
pension
 
funds
 
have
 
found
 
infrastructure
 
funds
 
like
 
GIP
 
to
 
better
 
align
 
with
 
their
 
interest
 
in
 
long-term,
 
responsible
 
management
 
of
 
assets.
 
Even
 
Department
 
witness
 
Addonizio
 
recognized
 
during
 
cross-examination
 
that
 
it
 
is
 
The
 
Partners
 
rather
 
than
 
stockholders
 
that
 
have
 
no
 
constraints
 
whatsoever
 
on
 
their
 
ability
 
to
 
make
 
or
 
withhold
 
investments
 
who
 
will
 
have
 
the
 
greatest
 
stake
 
in
 
the
 
health
 
and
 
success
 
of
 
the
 
utility
 
if
 
the
 
acquisition
 
is
 
approved.
13
 
 
The
 
most
 
important
 
evidence
 
in
 
the
 
record
 
with
 
respect
 
to
 
public
 
and
 
private
 
ownership
 
structures
 
is
 
the
 
testimony
 
of
 
Allete
 
witness
 
Jennifer
 
Cady
 
and
 
the
 
accompanying
 
analysis
 
of
 
recent
 
utility
 
take-private
 
transactions,
 
none
 
of
 
which
 
resulted
 
in
 
large
 
rate
 
increases.
14
 
While
 
electric
 
rates
 
are
 
rising
 
in
 
Minnesota
 
and
 
nationwide,
 
there
 
is
 
no
 
evidence
 
that
 
these
 
increases
 
are
 
connected
 
in
 
any
 
way
 
to
 
private
 
equity
 
or
 
infrastructure
 
fund
 
investment,
 
and
 
for
 
good
 
reason
 
–
 
the
 
ability
 
of
 
investor-owned
 
utilities
 
to
 
raise
 
rates
 
is
 
entirely
 
dependent
 
on
 
the
 
cooperation
 
of
 
regulators
 
which
 
is
 
not
 
affected
 
by
 
their
 
ownership
 
structures.
 
 
 
In
 
our
 
view,
 
a
 
decision
 
that
 
could
 
materially
 
impact
 
Minnesota
 
Power’s
 
ability
 
to
 
meet
 
100%
 
carbon-free
 
requirements
 
and
 
provide
 
reliable
 
service
 
should
 
not
 
be
 
based
 
on
 
unsubstantiated
 
fears,
 
but
 
on
 
the
 
facts
 
in
 
the
 
record
 
which
 
clearly
 
show
 
that
 
the
 
company
 
will
 
operate
 
under
 
the
 
same
 
regulatory
 
framework
 
with
 
greater
 
capacity
 
and
 
commitment
 
to
 
provision
 
of
 
much-needed
 
capital.
 
It
 
is
 
equally
 
important
 
not
 
to
 
consider
 
benefits
 
and
 
harms
 
in
 
a
 
vacuum,
 
but
 
to
 
evaluate
 
the
 
net
 
benefits
 
and
 
harms
 
of
 
the
 
proposed
 
transaction
 
compared
 
to
 
the
 
likely
 
result
 
of
 
its
 
rejection,
 
which
 
we
 
believe
 
include
 
instability,
 
rising
 
capital
 
costs
 
and
 
eventually
 
acquisition
 
of
 
the
 
utility
 
by
 
a
 
less
 
appealing
 
set
 
of
 
investors
 
on
 
less
 
favorable
 
terms.
 
 
 
While
 
we
 
believe
 
existing
 
regulatory
 
requirements
 
and
 
oversight
 
are
 
wholly
 
sufficient
 
to
 
ensure
 
that
 
the
 
proposed
 
transaction
 
delivers
 
net
 
incremental
 
benefits
 
compared
 
to
 
the
 
alternative
 
absent
 
additional
 
commitments,
 
we
 
appreciate
 
the
 
extensive
 
commitments
 
that
 
have
 
been
 
made
 
in
 
terms
 
of
 
governance,
 
provision
 
of
 
capital,
 
labor
 
relations,
 
maintenance
 
and
 
expansion
 
of
 
low
 
income
 
programs,
 
and
 
other
 
matters
 
and
 
believe
 
that
 
they
 
further
 
strengthen
 
the
 
case
 
for
 
approval.
 
We
 
urge
 
the
 
Commission
 
to
 
approve
 
the
 
transaction
 
as
 
proposed
 
by
 
Allete
 
and
 
The
 
Partners.

OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40399  
MPUC Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198 
MPUC Docket No. E-015/M -24-383 
 
INITIAL POST HEARING BRIEF  
 
 
 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 TABLE OF CONTENTS  
 
 i 
 
 INTRODUCTION ................................ ................................ ................................ .........................  1 
BACKGROUND  ................................ ................................ ................................ ...........................  3 
PROCEDURAL HISTORY  ................................ ................................ ................................ .........  5 
STANDARD OF REVIEW  ................................ ................................ ................................ ..........  7 
ANALYSIS  ................................ ................................ ................................ ................................ .... 8 
I. THE ACQUISITION WILL RESULT IN SIGNIFICANT BENEFITS FOR 
MINNESOTA POWER AND ITS CUSTOMERS.  ................................ .......................  9 
A. Reliable Access to Equity Capital from the Partners will Facilitate Minnesota 
Power’s Ability to Comply with the Carbon Free Standard.  ................................ .. 9 
B. The Partners have Made Additional Commitments in Support of the Public Interest.
................................ ................................ ................................ ...............................  37 
C. The Partners’ Expertise as Utility and Energy Investors can Benefit ALLETE and 
Minnesota Power’s Customers.  ................................ ................................ ............  38 
D. The Acquisition Provides Benefits by Ensuring Continuity of the Company’s 
Existing Values.  ................................ ................................ ................................ .... 48 
E. The Commission’s Authority Will Be Fully Maintained and Expanded by the 
Acquisition.  ................................ ................................ ................................ ...........  51 
II. THE SPECULATIVE RISKS IDENTIFIED BY OPPOSING PARTIES DO NOT 
OUTWEIGH THE BENEFITS.  ................................ ................................ ....................  54 
A. Opposing Parties’ Concerns about “Private Equity Investors” are Not Supported by

 INTRODUCTION  
In 2023, Minnesota passed a law requiring all utilities to decarbonize their systems over 
the next 15 years. Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691, subd. 2g (the “Carbon Free Standard”).1 The leaders 
and professionals at ALLETE2 analyzed what they would need to do in order to meet the Carbon 
Free Standard, along with their already existing needs to maintain or upgrade aging infrastructure, 
replace retiring generation, construct the  needed  transmission lines, and fulfill the Company’s  
over-riding obligation to provide safe, reliable, and affordable service. That analysis led the 
Company  to the conclusion that it needed to make a change.  
Through careful evaluation and deliberation, the Company  determined that acquisition by 
a group of private infrastructure investors and pension funds would enable the Company  to make 
the needed transformation to the Carbon Free Standard —without changing its underlying character 
as a utility focused on the communities it serves. Ultimately, the Company  selected Global 
Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments” 
and, together, “the Partners”) as the right fit. A s a result, the Partners entered into an agreement 
under which the Company  would be acquired by entities controlled by CPP Investments and GIP 
(“Acquisition”).3 
The Partners are proud to become part of the community in Northern Minnesota and to 
help Minnesota Power continue to meet its obligation to serve its customers, from residential 
customers across the Iron Range and the North Shore to the largest industrial operations in the 
State, and everyone in between. The Partners recognize and accept the obligations that will come

 with owning a public utility and will meet those obligations. In particular, the Partners understand 
the requirement for Minnesota Power to comply with the Carbon Free Standard and are committed 
to helping the Company achieve this goal.  Each  of the Partners has owned regulated public utilities , 
and has a clearly demonstrated track record of living up to the obligations  of an owner of a public 
utility  company .  
 The Acquisition should be approved because it is consistent with the public interest. It will 
eliminate the serious risk that the Company  will be unable to access the equity capital it needs to 
comply with the Carbon Free Standard. This very significant benefit to the public interest far 
outweighs any speculative risks of the Acquisition. It will also benefit the public interest through 
commitments related to affordability, workforce and labor protections, and continuity of leadership 
and core values at the Company . In addition, the Acquisition will benefit the public interest 
because it will allow the Company  to benefit from the Partners’ expertise investing in utilities  and 
renewables, and experience in financing advanced energy technologies. In light of  these benefits, 
the Acquisition has already been approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the 
Wisconsin Public Service Commission.  
The Acquisition will allow the Partners to invest  needed capital, subject to continued 
regulation by the Commission, to benefit Minnesota Power’s customers and the public interest. It 
will also ensure that Minnesota Power has the resources it needs for the future, and the stability it 
needs to chart its path tow ard that future. As demonstrated by substantial evidence in the record, 
the Acquisition is in the public interest, and should be approved.  The Partners request that the 
Administrative Law Judge recom mend, and that the Commission order, approval of the 
Acquisition.

 BACKGROUND  
As explained in more detail in the Petition, the Petitioners include Minnesota Power and 
the Partners. The Petition requests approval of a transaction by which the Partners would become 
the investors in ALLETE.4 Upon closing of the Acquisition, 40% of the interests in ALLETE will 
be held by CPP Investments, 40% of the interests in ALLETE will be held through GIP’s most 
recent fund, GIP Fund  V, and the other 20% of the interests in ALLETE will be held by a differen t 
GIP fund, Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P. (“Tower Bridge”).5   
CPP Investments is a professional investment management organization and an 
experienced infrastructure investor that manages approximately CAD $700 billion in Canada 
Pension Fund (“CPP”) assets, which are expected to grow to CAD $1 trillion over the next d ecade.6 
CPP Investments was created pursuant to an act of Canadian Parliament to invest funds not 
currently needed to pay benefits in the best interests of contributors and beneficiaries.7 Its 
investment decision s are overseen by an independent board of directors and it has an “investment -
only mandate” by law, meaning that it is prohibited from engaging in activities other than investing 
its assets.8 CPP Investments and its employees limit their involvement to an investment 
management role and do not perform the functions of senior officers or managers, or otherwise 
participate in the day -to-day managerial or operational control of any of the companie s in which 
it invests.9

STANDARD OF REVIEW  
Minnesota Statutes §  216B.50 p rovides that the Commission “shall give its consent” to the 
Acquisition if the Commission finds the Acquisition “consistent with the public interest .”26 The 
Commission has previously found that this standard does not require “an affirmative finding of 
public benefit ,”27 nor does it require the Acquisition to result in affirmative benefits.28 Rather, th e 
standard simply requires a finding that the Acquisition is compatible with the public interest.29 The 
Commission has established that, t o determine whether the Acquisition meets this standard , 
“perceived detriments or concerns must be weighed against perceived benefits to the public. If the 
perceived detriments do not outweigh the perceived benefits, the merger is deemed to be 
‘consistent with the public interest.’”30   
For the reasons explained below and based upon the substantial evidentiary record, the 
Acquisition readily meets this public interest standard  and should be approved .

 ANALYSIS  
The record demonstrates that the Acquisition will result in meaningful net benefits to the 
public interest.  These benefits include providing  ALLETE  a stable, reliable , and patient source of 
equity capital that will enable  Minnesota Power  to make the substantial investments needed to 
meet its obligations, including  compliance  with Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard. The 
Acquisition will also enable ALLETE to leverage the Partners ’ expertise as ALLETE transitions 
Minnesota Power to an increasingly cleaner syste m. There will be no adverse impact on customers, 
service cost or quality, employees, or communities. While Parties have claimed that there are risks 
associated with the Acquisition, these claims  are based on speculation, unsupported by evidence, 
and have been  thoroughly  addressed by the comprehensive conditions that the Petitioners have 
proposed for  this Acquisition.   
Further, in evaluating the public interest it is important to recognize that denial of the 
Acquisition would create  significant risk s to the public interest . The question at hand is not whether 
the Acquisition will result in a change, but whether the change represented by the Acquisition is 
consistent with  the public interest compared to the significant risks of maintaining the status quo.  
As noted by the OAG, the Carbon Free Standard is “pretty dang important,”31 and any risks to the 
Company’s compliance wi th it should  be given substantial weight. The record is clear that the 
Acquisition will avoid the substantial risks of forcing Minnesota Power to continue to rely on 
public markets to complete the energy transition , while providing additional benefits to the public 
interest including rate reductions, additional funding for affordability programs, certainty for the 
Company’s workforce , and allowing the Company to benefit from the Partners’ experience.

 The record in this proceeding demonstrates that the Acquisition is not only consistent with 
the public interest, but is better for the public interest  than the status quo. Accordingly, the 
Acquisition should be approved .  
I. THE ACQUISITION WILL RESULT IN SIGNIFICANT BENEFITS FOR 
MINNESOTA POWER AND ITS CUSTOMERS . 
A. Reliable  Access to  Equity  Capital from the Partners will Facilitate  Minnesota 
Power’s Ability to  Comply with the Carbon Free Standard . 
One of the key benefits of the Acquisition is that it will ensure Minnesota Power has 
reliable access to the equity capital it needs to meet its obligations to ensure safe, reliable, high 
quality electric service and comply with the Carbon Free Standard. A LLETE  correctly  determined 
that meeting these obligations would require a substantial, unprecedented level of equity capital 
going forward. Further, ALLETE determined that it would be unreasonable —and in fact very risky 
—to rely on public markets to provid e the equity capital needed for these investments.  
As a result, ALLETE began a years -long evaluation and ultimately concluded the 
Acquisition was needed to ensure reliable and cost -effective access to the required equity capital 
for these investments.  The evidence in the record demonstrates that ALLETE was right.  
1. Minnesota Power ’s Capital Needs are Growing Dramatically because of 
the Carbon Free Standard . 
The Company , like any responsible business, continually evaluates how to provide high -
quality service to its customers while meeting all of its obligations .32 These obligations includ e 
provid ing safe, reliable, affordable, and increasingly clean energy.  
In recent years, changes in Minnesota energy policy have created significant new 
requirements for Minnesota Power. The most significant of these is the Carbon Free Standard, 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691, subd. 2g, which will require Minnesota Power to make substantial

a) Minnesota Power ’s Capital Needs are Growing Substantially .

several times larger than ALLETE’s prior capital expenditure levels. As explained by Witness 
Taran and reflected in Figure 1 below, the five -year investment plan is approximately 3.8 times 
larger than the historical average.35

A substantial portion of the investments required for the next five years, and the years beyond, are 
related to transmission projects that have already been approved by the Commission and that the 
Company will need to fund.40 These capital needs are not in question – they are a certainty.  
These capital requirements are enormous compared to Minnesota Power’s past levels of 
investments, and they will require a significant increase in equity capital to fund. The magnitude 
of this need can be measured in several ways.  
First,  as Witness Taran explained, the 2025 -2029 capital plan for Minnesota Power 
represents more than 100 percent of ALLETE’s market capitalization.41 In other words, Minnesota 
Power forecasts that in the next five years it will make investments that are greater than the current 
equity value of the Company.  
Second, to fund these investments over the next five years ALLETE will need to issue 
more equity capital tha n it has obtained over its entire 75 -year history as a publicly traded utility,42 
also representing a  substantial  change from business -as-usual.

 a) Publicly Traded Companies Obtain Equity Investment by Issuing 
New Shares in Public Markets.  
Regulated utilities like Minnesota Power fund capital investments using debt and equity.73 
Minnesota Power obtains debt financing by issuing first mortgage bonds, generally to large 
financial institutions, and plans to continue to do so.74 Historically, Minnesota Power has obtained 
equity capital by issuing common shares to potential investors through public stock markets.75 
Minnesota Power has issued many shares of stock, and they are continuously traded among public 
investors both large and small. ALLETE does not receive any capital when its existing shares are 
traded. In order to obtain equity capital, ALLETE must issue ne w shares, a process that involves 
significant time, cost and risk.76 
The record clearly shows that ALLETE would need to raise more than $1 billion in new 
equity to fund its expected investment requirements over the next five years.77 In comparison, the 
Company has raised only $1.3 billion in equity from public markets in the 75 years it has been 
publicly traded.78 
b) Relying on Public Markets for Equity Capital in the Future would 
be Risky for ALLETE and Minnesota Power Customers . 
In the face of this unprecedented increase in its need for equity capital, ALLETE analyzed 
its options. One option was  to attempt  to continue as a small publicly traded company and rely on 
the public markets for equity capital; ALLETE referred to this as the standalone financing plan.

 A serial issuer faces several problems that increase the challenges of relying on public 
markets. Because it issues new shares so frequently, a serial issuer faces the possibility of investor 
fatigue —when large volumes of new shares are issued each year, p ublic market investors are less 
interested in investing.103 A serial issuer also faces uncertainty about the timing —rather than being 
able to issue public equity at the most advantageous times, a serial issuer is forced to continue 
issuing regardless of mark et conditions.  
Fourth, the record demonstrates a real -world example —of a Minnesota utility —that was 
not able to obtain the capital it needed from public markets. As described by Witness  
Quackenbush, on September 15, 2008, Otter Tail Corporation  (“OTC”),  the parent company of the 
Minnesota electric utility Otter Tail Power Company, announced a public offering of 5 million 
shares.104 At the time of the announcement, its stock price was $39.95, suggesting that OTC could 
sell 5 million shares and raise approximately $200 millio n from its public offering, before 
underwriting costs.105 Contrary to expectations, OTC was only able to issue 4.5 million shares at 
the price of $30.00, meaning that it raised only 65 percent of the equity capital it sought .106  
The effect on OTC and its customers continues to this day. Because the public market 
volatility affected OTC’s offering, OTC ultimately issued approximately 1.3 million more shares 
than anticipated at the time of announcement to obtain the relatively small amount of capital 
raised.107 As a result, over the last 16 years, OTC has paid approximately $29 million in dividends

These risks could negatively impact customers and the public interest in several ways.

to dismiss, offhand, the possibility that public market funding might not appear when needed, the 
record demonstrates that it can and has happened.111 If Minnesota Power is not able to obtain the 
equity capital it needs, some investments will need to be delayed or abandoned. Challenges 
obtaining funding could jeopardize Minnesota Power’s share of transmission projects already 
approved by MISO and the Commission. Most importantly, it could impact plans for compliance 
with the Carbon Free Standard . As Witness  Scissons explained, “ it would be highly unlikely the 
Company could achieve its carbon free goals as planned ” without the Acquisition.112 
Second, even if Minnesota Power is able to get the equity capital it needs from public 
markets, the record shows a substantial risk that doing so could increase Minnesota Power’s cost 
of capital to the detriment of ratepayers. As Witnesses Taran, Scissons and Quackenbush observed, 
raising the necessary public capital would invariably require serial issuances, which would in turn

For instance, each time ALLETE issues public equity, it increases its current dividend obligations.

the patient equity made available by the Partners.

3. Acquisition by the Partners will Avoid the Risks of Relying on Public 
Markets to Comply with the Carbon Free Standard . 
The Acquisition will avoid the risks of relying on public markets. Instead of hoping  that 
public markets will provide the dramatically increased  equity  capital Minnesota Power requires  at 
the time it is required , the Acquisition will provide a sure and steady source of capital . The 
Acquisition will protect Minnesota Power and its customers from the uncertainty and risk of 
relying on public markets. The cycle described above, in which serial equity issuances create cash 
flow problems, which in turn require m ore equity issuances, can be avoided entirely. Instead of 
spending time and resources figuring out how to get the capital it needs to fund the energy 
transition, the reliable and stable capital provided by the Partners will allow Minnesota Power to 
spend i ts time identifying  and implementing  creative solutions to the challenges of the energy 
transition. This key benefit of the Acquisition is the avoidance of risk . As described above, the risk 
of relying on public markets is real and material —and the Acquisi tion will avoid that risk entirely.  
The Opposing Parties entirely ignore this risk and incorrectly assume, without review or analysis, 
that the old way of doing business will continue to work.  
One clear benefit of the Acquisition is that the Partners will provide patient  equity capital. 
Investors in public markets, as discussed above, expect regular quarterly dividends. The record 
demonstrates that when those regular dividends are not paid, public investors punish publicly 
traded companies.135 The record also shows that the requirement to pay these dividends will

 A. Opposing Parties ’ Concerns about “Private Equity Investors ” are Not 
Supported by the Record . 
Many of the arguments raised by  the Opposing Parties are based on their overgenera lized 
fears about what  “private equity investors” may do when they buy a company.212 These fears are 
based on a generic understanding of “private equity investors,” sometimes literally based on 
concerns that Opposing Parties have read about in books.213 These characterizations, and the 
resulting fears about what the Partners will or will not do, are not supported by the record , for 
several reasons.  
First, the Partners are not stereo typical private equity investors.  While the Opposing Parties 
seek to paint all investors  as opportunistic and bad for the public interest , the record shows that 
they did not do their homework before assigning labels and making assumptions about the 
Partners.  As explained by the Department , investors have different categories of investments, and 
they carry different characteristics and goals.214 One category is private equity,  another is public 
equity (such as public stock mar kets). Yet another category is real assets, including  infrastructure. 
The Opposing Parties assumed that the Partners are investing in the Company as “private equity” 
investors and  base many of their concerns on that assumption. In fact, the Partners have categorized 
ALLETE as a real asset or infrastructure investment, and have no intention of handling the

service quality and reliability.237 In each of these proceedings, the Commission , based on input

the Acquisition could, somehow, increase risks or harm customers. There  is no reason to believe 
that the Commission —or the Parties in this case —will be any less diligent in the future . The 
Commission will continue to protect the public interest after the Acquisition, as it has done for 
many years , and has the regulatory authority t o address any issues that do arise.

rates. Additionally, utilities also must s eek approval for their actual capital structure and must 
propose to the Commission a ratio of equity to debt, as well as a contingency range for that ratio,

customer rates but places limits on the financing of the utility. The Commission engages in both 
of these functions as it relates to Minnesota Power (through rate cases) and ALLETE (through 
capital structure filing s). As a result, if the Acquisition is approved, the levels of debt at Minnesota 
Power (for ratemaking) and ALLETE (for capital structure) will continue to be closely regulated

 explained by the Department, double leverage occurs when a parent company issues debt and 
infuses some of the resulting cash as equity into a subsidiary.277  
The only way to avoid “double leverage” would be to finance a company without any debt. 
Since cash is fungible once obtained, any debt issuance that is later followed by an equity infusion 
to a subsidiary could involve “double leverage” as it is defined by  the Department. The only way 
to be sure that debt issued by a parent is not infused as equity to a subsidiary would be to use no 
debt at all.  
Financing Alloy Parent without any debt would not be consistent with the financing theory 
laid out by  the Department. As discussed above,  every business —including Alloy Parent —has an 
optimal capital structure that will result in the lowest cost of capital, and which includes some debt 
and some equity.278 Financing the business entirely from equity would result in less efficient 
financing than is optimal, and would serve only to make it more expensive for the Partners to 
provide the capital that Minnesota Powe r needs.   
As noted above, the use of debt financing is a  standard  industry practice.  In fact, the 
Department provided specific analysis about the possible benefits of debt financing.279 While 
Opposing Parties  argues that the benefits of debt financing are outweighed by risk at some point, 
no Opposing Party  has done any analysis about the point at which the benefits of using debt would 
be outweighed by the risk.  As explained above, the Partners intend to manage the amount of debt 
at Alloy Parent at a level that is consistent with industry standards and target investment grade 
credit metrics , which means that there is very limited risk from the use of debt financing.

at the Company, either as direct debt service (due to higher borrowing costs at ALLETE), or

committed that they cannot receive dividends if ALLETE does not have an investment grade credit 
rating.281 This ensures that dividends to Alloy Parent do not negatively impact ALLETE’s credit 
ratings or Minnesota Power’s financing costs. In addition, the Partners have committed that they 
will not receive any dividends that would cause Minnesota Power to be out  of compliance with its 
required capital structure, ensuring that the utility is financed consistent with Commission

There is one genuine risk that the record does support but that the Opposing Parties fail to

to consider and address the risks to Minnesota Power and its customers if the Acquisition is not 
approved.  As Company Witness Taran explained, there are significant risks of a credit downgrade 
and cost of debt increase if the Acquisition does not close.295 Indeed, given ALLETE’s significant 
need for capital, the curren t market uncertainty surrounding several key customers, the historic 
volatility of the public equity market, and the signal it would send to the market if the Acquisition 
is not approved, the most profound risks to ALLETE, its credit rating, and its cost o f capital, and 
thus the most clear and profound risk to Minnesota Power’s customers, would come from failure 
to approve the Acquisition.
