1. The Opposing Parties Do Not Understand the Financial Evaluations 
Performed by the Partners . 
The first error made by Opposing Parties is to confuse the Partners’ due diligence financial 
evaluation s that are presented to their respective Investment Committees as some sort of over -
arching plan for ALLETE. In particular, Opposing Parties point to the Partners’ IC Memos  as 
evidence that the Partners intend to take advantage of ALLETE to increase their returns.298 These 
arguments demonstrate that the Opposing Parties do not understand what the IC Memos are , or for 
what they are used.  
As explained above, an IC Memo  is a tool that sophisticated  investors use to evaluate 
whether to make an investment. As part of that evaluation, it should be no surprise that investors 
try to estimate what return they could expect to receive. Just as a prudent person would compare 
the potential return on different stocks or mutual funds before making an investment, investors 
like the Partners evaluate and compare the potential return on investments like ALLETE.  
That evaluation involves inputting a series of assumptions, forecasts, and other data into a 
valuation model.299 The valuation model then outputs an estimated level of return that could be 
expected based on the inputs. The fact that the valuation model resulted in an expected return of

 F. The Affiliated Interest Statute and Commitments by the Petitioners will 
Ensure there is no Self -Dealing . 
The Commission’s existing affiliated interest regulations and the additional commitments 
offered by the Petitioners will ensure that customers are protected from the risks of self -dealing 
between Minnesota Power and the other investments of the Partners.  
1. The Commission ’s Affiliated Interest Requirements  are Intended to Protect 
against the Risk of Self-Dealing.  
The Commission has been effectively regulating the risks of affiliated interests for many 
years based on consistent interpretations of existing  legal requirements. In general, Minn. Stat.  
§ 216B.48 (“the Affiliated Interest Statute”) requires that utilities identify “affiliated interests” in 
an annual report each year, disclose any contracts or agreements over $50,000 with those affiliated 
interests to the Commission, and receive Commission  approval.354 
The Commission has the exclusive authority to set public utility rates,355 including the 
authority to evaluate the cost of every contract before it is included in rates. That analysis typically 
takes place at the time a public utility requests recovery of costs,356 and the Commission can 
exclude some or all of a utility’s contract c osts from rates if it identifies problems. In contrast, t he 
primary purpose of the Affiliated Interest Statute is to  identify a subset of contracts where there 
could be heightened concerns regarding self -dealing, and  give the Commission an opportunity to  
assert jurisdiction over the agreement earlier in the process.357

include a signed certification from the Company and the supplier that the contract was entered into 
at arms -length . The reporting is designed to be comprehensive. As explained by Witness 
Anderson, the $1 million threshold would have captured 75 percent of purchase order spending, 
and 94 percent of non -purchase order spending, during 2024. This proposal was intentionally 
crafted to respond to concerns raised about the potential for self -dealing and the impact it could 
have on customers.  
This reporting is in excess of what is required by law and what the Commission receives 
from other utilities. For each contract disclosed, the Commission, the Department, the OAG, and 
any other interested party will be able to evaluate potential issues, as k the Company for 
information, and investigate if any concerns arise. If problems are identified, the Commission will 
have full authority to ensure that any related costs are not included in rates and take other necessary 
actions.

Energy, Otter Tail Power, CenterPoint, MERC, and Greater Minnesota Gas are all owned more 
than 5 percent by BlackRock and Vanguard. The Department’s interpretation of the Affiliated 
Interest Statute would mean that all of those utilit ies are also affiliated interests with the entire

G. The Commission has the Authority to Enforce the Commitments of the 
Acquisition, and Continuing Enforcement Authority over Minnesota Power.  
Opposing Parties suggest that the commitments the Petitioners have offered carry less 
weight because they are not enforceable. They are wrong —any commitments incorporated into a 
Commission order are clearly enforceable under the law, and the Commission has  ongoing 
authority over Minnesota Power going forward, as previously discussed.  
To be clear, the Partners and the Company intend that the commitments offered in this 
proceeding are binding and enforceable. To the extent there is any doubt —which there should not 
be, as described below —the Partners further commit that any failure to ach ieve any commitment 
in this Settlement or to comply with any other condition the Commission places on approval of the 
Acquisition, will be a violation of the Commission’s order under Minnesota law, and enforceable 
against the entity for whom the action (or  non-action) is required.  
The Partners have not previously made this commitment because it is a restatement of 
existing law, and it should be clear that any commitments included in a Commission order would 
be enforceable.  Minn. Stat. § 216B.54  provides :  
Whenever the commission or department shall be of the opinion that any person or 
public utility is failing or omitting or is about to fail or omit to do anything required 
of it … by any order of the commission , or is doing anything or about to do 
anything, or permitting anything or about to permit anything to be done, contrary 
to or in violation of … any order of the commission , it shall refer the matter to the 
attorney general who shall take appropriate legal action.

 “Person” is defined in Minn. Stat. § 216B.02, subd. 3 and includes partnerships and corporations, 
including the Partners and Alloy Parent. Minn. Stat. § 216B.57 also provides that any person, as 
defined, who knowingly and intentionally violates or fails to  obey a Commission order is subject 
to financial penalties. There can be no serious doubt that these provisions apply to the 
commitments offered by the Petitioners, which will be included in a Commission order.  
 Some of the commitments offered by the Commission are, theoretically, outside the 
standard authority of the Commission. For example, the Commission cannot order the shareholders 
of a utility to make non -recoverable contributions to low -income programs. It is also not clear 
whether the Commission has authority to prohibit or limit a public utility from paying dividends 
to its shareholders, or require shareholders to provide equity capital. But the Commission has a 
long history of accepting commitments from utilities that are beyond its authority to impose against 
the objections of a party —and when those commitments are incorporated into a Commission order 
and accepted by the party, they become binding and enforceable.385 The Commission has 
specifically done so in merger dockets,386 and those commitments have been enforced at later

K. The Acquisition Will Not Result in Rate Increases . 
Several Opposing Parties raise concerns  that the Acquisition will result in increased rates 
for customers. They are wrong. In fact, substantial evidence in the record demonstrates 
conclusively that the Acquisition will not result in increased rates and may actually  decrease rates 
compared to the status quo. Further, while some Opposing Parties raise concerns regarding future 
rate impacts, the record demonstrates  that those concerns are speculative, exaggerated, and 
unrelated to the Acquisition.  
1. The Acquisition Will Not Increase Rates because t he Petitioners have 
Committed to Not Seek Recovery in Rates of Specific Costs. 
The record demonstrates that the Acquisition will not result in increased costs. The 
Petitioners have committed that they will not seek recovery of several non -recurring costs related 
to the Acquisition, including: (1) the acquisition premium paid to obtain ownership of ALLETE; 
(2) transaction costs relating to the Acquisition; and (3 ) transition costs.420  Opposing Parties have 
not identified any specific cost caused by the Acquisition that the Petitioners have not already 
agreed will be non -recoverable.  
2. The Acquisition May Reduce Rates Compared to the Status Quo. 
The Petitioners have also committed that, in the future, Minnesota Power will no longer 
seek recovery of certain costs that it currently recovers in rates. Specifically, the Petitioners have 
committed that that as long as the Partners are owners of ALLETE, they will not seek recovery of: 
(1) compensation or expenses for Board members that are not independent ;421 (2) investor relations

was resolved by a settlement that included costs related to Board compensation and Investor 
Relations. The rate case s ettlement explicitly includes $0.66 million in costs related to Board 
compensation and expenses.424 The rate case settlement  also includes the initial proposed amount 
of Investor Relations costs, for a total of $0.17 million.425 While the rate case settlement  was silent 
as it relates to flotation costs, the Commission has approved their inclusion in the past .426

the parent company of Minnesota Energ y Resources Corporation by Wisconsin Energy 
Corporation, the Commission specifically held that cost savings are not necessary for a transaction 
to be in the public interest:  
The Commission declines to require that MERC either prove that the merger has 
resulted in cost savings or have savings imputed to its revenues.  
 
MERC has argued persuasively that the goal of the merger is not to achieve 
immediate synergies but rather to better position the merged companies to access 
capital and invest in infrastructure and customer -service improvements. Moreover,

3. The Acquisition Will Not Cause Long-Term Rate Impacts .   
Some Opposing Parties suggest that the Partners or the Acquisition will cause Minnesota 
Power’s rates to increase in the future. They are wrong for several reasons.  
First, the record contains substantial evidence demonstrating that Minnesota Power’s rate 
of return will not change because of the Acquisition. There is no dispute that the Commission will 
continue to have authority to set the return on equity for Minnesota Power . Further, as discussed 
above, it is not likely that the Acquisition will have any impact on Minnesota Power’s cost of debt 
and—even if that were to occur —the Petitioners have committed that customers will be held 
harmless from any impacts to the co st of debt caused by the Acquisition. As a result, the 
Acquisition will have no impact on the cost of capital used to set Minnesota Power’s rates.  
Second, the Partners cannot increase Minnesota Power’s rates. Only the Commission can 
set rates. Further, when the Commission sets rates, the rates are required by law to be based on the

20156 -111752 -01.

 cost of service.428 In other words, Minnesota Power’s rates will always be approved by the 
Commission, and they will include only those costs that are necessary to provide safe, reliable, 
and affordable utility service.  As a result, it is not possible for rates to increase unless the 
Commission determines that it is reasonable and necessary to do so.  
 Third , while the record includes some forecasts suggesting potential rate increases in the 
future, they are entirely speculative and, even if they do occur, would not be caused by the 
Acquisition. They are, instead, caused by the need for Minnesota Power to make material 
investments in its system to provide safe, reliable, and affordable power, and to comply with the 
Carbon Free Standard.  
Opposing Parties seem to suggest that the record includes specific plans by the Partners to 
increase rates in the future.429 That is not the case. The Partners do not have a “rate increase plan,” 
because a) the Partners understand that the Commission sets the rates, not investors or the 
Company , and b) the Partners will be investor -owners, and will not make day-to-day decisions 
regarding  what investments need to be made to provide service.  
While the Partners do not have any plan relat ed to future rates —or any ability to implement 
a plan if it did exist —it is possible that Minnesota Power’s rates will increase in the future. The 
fundamental purpose of this Acquisition is to ensure that Minnesota Power has sufficient capital 
to make the investments needed for the energy transition. It is undisputed that doing so will require 
substantial investment . For example, Minnesota Power forecast s that it must invest $4.6 billion in 
the next five years. I f these investments are made, they will increase Minnesota Power’s rate base 
and that will have an impact on rates , although that impact is not yet known.  Such increases will

CONCLUSION  
 For all of the foregoing  reasons, the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest and 
should be approved. ALLETE and Minnesota Power need to significantly increase investments to 
continue providing safe, reliable, affordable, and increasingly clean energy to customers. Rel ying 
on public markets for equity capital would be very risky for customers, and the Acquisition will 
avoid that risk. The Acquisition will also allow the Company to benefit from the Partners’ 
expertise, and provide the additional benefits from  the Petitioners’ commitments. In contrast, the

Dear Judge McKenzie : 
Enclosed  via e -Filing,  please find the  public and highly confidential trade secret (“HCTS”)  
versions of the Initial Post Hearing Brief (“Initial Brief”) on behalf of Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Management, LLC  (together, the “Partners”)  in the 
above -entitled docket s.   
 
The Initial Brief contains  information that has been previously designated as HCTS Information  
in this proceeding . The Partners have taken reasonable efforts to keep this information  secret  
and it has not been provided to any individual outside of the Partners , senior leadership of 
ALLETE , or those subject to the Protective Orders issued in this proceeding . The data derives 
independent economic value from not being available to the public.  
 
Pursuant to the Protective Order for Highly Confidential Trade Secret Data issued December 16, 
2024, t he information marked as HCTS  Information  is competitively sensitive information that 
would impose a serious business risk if disseminated. The information marked as HCTS 
Information in the Initial Brief has been previously designated as such and this designation has 
been upheld throughout the course of this proceeding.

 3 INTRODUCTION   
 In 2023 Minnesota passed a carbon -free energy standard, now codified in Minnesota 
Statute 216B.1691, Subd ivision s 1(b) and 2g. The law, while historic, contains several 
concessions that make compliance with the 100-percent -carbon -free-by-2040 standard 
(CFS) easier , including the ability to offset carbon -heavy electrical production with credits 
from other jurisdictions.1 The Minnesota Public Utility Commission’s (Commission) ability 
to punish utilities for noncompliance with fines is effectively limited to however much it 
would cost to buy such credits.2 The Commission also is charged with administering what 
has been called an “off ramp,” allowing for modification or delay of the CFS “if the 
commission determines that modifying or delaying the standard obligation is in the public 
interest.”3  
 In this proceeding the Commission is presented with potential new utility owners  
suggesting that they offer  the only way that one of Minnesota’s utilities could possibly 
comply with the CFS  standard. These are not companies that possess a history  of experience 
in administering Minnesota regulated utilities, rather they bring wealth y investors , and an 
intention to create more wealth for those investors . The companies seeking to control 
Minnesota Power  (MP) , Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global 
Infrastructure Partners (GIP) (collectively “the Partners”), view MP’s parent company, 
ALLETE, as an attractive investment for their private equity clients. Utilities are historically 
 
1 Minn. Stat.  § 216B.1691 , Subd. 4(b)  (2024 ). 
2 Id. at Subd. 7  (Stating in part: “The penalty may not exceed the lesser of the cost of 
constructing facilities or purchasing credits.” ). 
3 Id. at Subd. 2b.  
 
 
 
 4 good investments;  they produce reliable returns and have the legal right to engage in 
monopolistic business  under the oversight of the Commission . The Partners have done 
quite a lot of analysis and have decided that this deal is a good one , for them.  
 However, the Commission does not exist to support the interests  of private 
investors, it exists to assure reliable and affordable service to the public by Minnesota’s 
regulated utilities. In this case it can only approve the takeover of ALLETE by the Partners 
if the transaction is cons istent wi th the public interest and the company to be sold has been 
correctly valued.4 If the transaction is not consistent with the public interest , it must be 
rejected.  
 The Partners and ALLETE  (collectively “the Applicants”) argue that  MP’s duties 
under  the CFS necessitate this deal, and that only through this deal can MP comply with 
the law and invest the necessary equity to decarbonize its energy generation. The reasoning 
of this application invites  the Commission to gamble on the possibility  that only these two 
owners will be able to guide MP through the transformation required by Minnesota’s 
historic 2023 law.  
However, evidence in the record shows that that gamble is a serious risk to 
Minnesota and to MP’s  customers. Putting all MP’s  eggs in this basket risks cutting off: 
other sources of funding; information from public reporting that is currently required of 
the utility and benefits the Commission and the public; the consistent services provided by 
MP’s  current workforce; and the access the MP now has to additional f unding through 
 
4 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 , Subd. 1  (2024).  
 
 
 
 5 public markets . This transaction risks saddling a Minnesota utility with large amounts of 
debt —debt that ultimately will be paid by MP customers one way or another. This 
transaction also increases the risk of bankruptcy, an occurrence that is thankfully rare 
among utilities , but has been caused by private equity owners in the recent past. Despite 
the Applicants’ arguments otherwise , all of this additional risk and the Partners’ avowed 
profit interests also risk the viability of MP meeting the CFS on the expected timeline.  
 For these reasons the Commission should reject this deal and encourage the 
Applicants to rethink the high amounts of profit they seek, and whether or not they should 
invest their money elsewhere rather than putting strain and increasing risk on a Minnesot a 
utility and its customers.   
STANDARD OF REVIEW  
 
Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 , Subd ivision  1, mandates that no public utility can sell, 
transfer, or merge assets or securities valued at $1,000,000 or more without prior approval 
from the Commission. The Commission’s analysis for any such  approval is straightforward: 
it must find that the proposed transaction is “consistent with the public interest.”5  This 
statutory language entrusts the Commission with the significant responsibility to ensure 
that utility mergers and acquisitions genuinely serve Minnesota’s public, not mer ely private 
investors.  
The Commission has long interpreted the public  interest standard through a 
balancing test, carefully weighing the harms and benefits of any proposed action  along with 
 
5 Id. 
 
 
 
 6 the method used to reach the agreement .6 The standard demands that the proposed 
transaction does not conflict  with or contravene interests such as affordability, reliability, 
transparency, and sound financial management of a public, regulated ut ility. In practical 
terms, this means that the Commission evaluates several critical factors: impacts on 
customer rates, potential risks to service  reliability , changes to market power, the financial 
integrity o f the utility post -acquisition, and the continued effectiveness of regulatory 
oversight.7  
The Commission’s past merger and acquisition decisions consistently  demonstrate 
that satisfying the public interest standard requires more than just avoiding harm; it 
requires  credible, enforceable commitments that pr oduce  concrete benefits.8 Similarly, the 
 
6 See, e.g., Order Approving Acquisition, with Conditions, In re Request for Approval of the 
Acquisition by MDU Res. Grp., Inc., and Great Plains Nat. Gas Co. of Cascade Nat. Gas 
Corp. , Docket No. G-004/PA -06-1585, at 2 , 8, eDockets Document No. 3943867 ; Order 
Approving Merger and Adopting Amended Stipulation with Modifications, In re Proposed 
Merger of Minnegasco, Inc. with and into Arkla, Inc. , at 5, e Docket s Document  No. 403630  
(“The Commission did more than examine a balance sheet of possible costs and benefits 
of the merger. It also evaluated the process by which the parties arrived at a stipulation to 
present to the Commission.”).  
7 Id.; see also  Order Approving Merger Subject to Conditions, In re Request for Approval of 
the Merger Agreement Between Integrys Energy Group, Inc. and Wisconsin Energy 
Corporation , at 5, eDocket s Document  No. 20156 -111752 -01. 
8 In the 2000 merger of Northern States Power and New  Century Energies to form Xcel 
Energy, the Commission’s approval was based on  a package of customer protections and 
safeguards. These included a guaranteed immediate rate cut, a five -year base rate freeze, 
and (soon after)  binding commitments that Minne sota ratepayers would never subsidize 
the u tility’s unregulated or foreign ventures.  The Commission also required public 
reporting on generation and commitments  to CO2 mitigation. Taken together, these 
provisions demonstrate d not just an absence of harm but a desire to ensure that  the deal 
was in alignment with the long -term public interest.  See Order Approving Merger, as 
Conditioned, In re Application Northern States Power  Co. for Approval to merge with New 
Century Energies, Inc. , eDocket s Document  No. 789046 .  
 
 
 
 7 Commission has consistently required a clear showing that ratepayers would not fund any 
part of the acquisition premium or transaction costs.9 These require ments further reflect 
the Commission’s broad scope in protecting the public interest . The Commission hasn’t 
just sought to mitigate financial impacts ; they’ve affirmatively sought to protect both 
continuity in service  and organizational transparency . 
Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 establishes that the valuation of the asset to be 
transferred is an essential element  of any showing that the proposal is “consistent with the 
public interest.” The  Commission “ shall take into consideration the reasonable value of the 
property, plant, or securities to be acquired or disposed of .”10 Historically,  the Commission 
has refrained from relying solely on applicants’ submissions and instead expects robust 
evidence and independent analysis from intervenors and expert witnesses to inform its 
judgments.11 Where an acqui sition price significantly exceeds book or market value, the 
Commission has required that such premium will not adversely impact ratepayers or 
undermine the utility’s ability to deliver reliable service at reasonable rates.12 
 
  
 
9 But beyond those financial protections, the Commission evaluated the 2015 Wisconsin 
Energy Corporation ’s acquisition  of Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation  (MERC ) for 
potential effects on service quality, workforce stability, and MERC ’s post -merger capital 
structure. It approved the transaction only after incorporating  conditions that ensured 
MERC would remain financially sound, adequately staffed, and subject to full Minnesota 
regulatory oversight. See supra , note 7, Order  Approving Merger Subject to Conditions .  
10 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 .  
11 Supra note 6,  Order Approving Merger and Adopting Amended Stipulation with 
Modifications . 
12 Id.  
 
 
 
 8 ANALYSIS  
I. The Applicants have not demonstrated any benefit to customers or 
Minnesota  
 
Nowhere in this record have the Applicants proven that this transaction is necessary 
for MP to continue to provide reliable and affordable electrical service in the years to come. 
This alone should cause the Commission to look at this transaction with serious skepticism, 
as it cannot proceed if there is not evidence  that the  acquisition is consistent with the 
public interest. Testimony offered by CURE’s experts help to further illustrate the failure of 
the Applicant’s submissions and witnesses to make a plausible case.  
 Mr. Ellis, a former utility executive with decades of experience leading energy 
strategy for  Sempra Energy, McKinsey & Company, and ExxonMobil ,13 found that 
“proceeding with this transaction would obfuscate and exacerbate” the cost of meeting the 
state’s CFS,14 ostensibly the applicants’ main justification for the transaction.  His detailed 
analysis shows that without a n updated  and accurate  valuation including  a reassessment 
of the authorized Return on Equity (ROE) for Minnesota Power (MP) , this transaction will 
push  the ratepayer  burden  for capital spending  40 percent higher than what is reasonable  
or needed .15 This mean s that customers  will be excessively burdened , and MP’s new owners 
will be excessively incentivized to maximize capital spending regardless of the 
environmental  benefit  from such overspending .16 He concludes : “In short, [this transaction 
creates] the potential for a MP customer [triple]-whammy  — higher rates, rising faster, for 
 
13 See Ex. CURE -601 (Schedule ME -1, Statement of Qualifications of Mark E. Ellis ). 
14 Ex. CURE -601 (Mark Ellis Direct Testimony), at 7. 
15 Id. at 63.  
16 Id.  
 
 
 
 9 a possibly worse environmental outcome. ”17 His testimony also describes in detail how the 
Commission could avoid this outcome with some fundamental changes in how it sets ROE 
and evaluates  the value of regulated utilities’ values. CURE submitted relevant discovery 
requests to Applicant witnesses regarding their criticisms of Mr. Ellis’s economic analysis, 
but other than offering critiques of the tone that Mr. Ellis took, their responses largely did 
not engage with the substance of his points that ROE and valuation are key issues that the 
Commission must assess in order to assure this acquisition is not contrary to the public 
interest.18 
 Mr. Ellis  noted that in the past nine  years MP ’s electric  rates have increased much 
faster than in flation —a full 2.3 times the inflation rate and much more than utilit ies as a 
whole19—and he provided considerable  analysis of future rate impacts that will be 
attributable to this transaction.  It is important to note that much of Mr. Ellis ’s analysis is 
veiled behind  Highly Confidential Trade Secret  (HCTS ) status , a designation made by the 
Applicants for much of the relevant documents in this case,  because it would have been 
impossible for him to do the ne cessary calculations on rate impacts withou t accessing this 
information.  While this data is shielded  from public view, the Commission has full access 
 
17 Id. at 64.  
18 Ex. CURE -603 (Mark Ellis Surrebuttal Testimony), at 10  (“Witnesses Bram, Bulkley, and 
Quackenbush all noted my use of this terminology. None addressed, denied, refuted, or 
identified any flaw in the substance of my argument that excessive ROEs impose 
unnecessary costs on customers that redound to the benefit of the owners of utilities.  
They appear to be more concerned with style than substance. ”); see generally id. 11–59 
(addressing rebuttal testimony of Bulkley, Alley, Bram, and Quackenbush, and citing 
discovery responses attached to testimony demonstrating a lack of credible or substantive 
disagreement with Mr. Ellis’s excessive ROE and valuation analys es). 
19 Ex. CURE -601 ( Mark Ellis Direct Testimony ), at 9.  
 
 
 
 10 to this analysis based on HCTS  documents,  and should  take to h eart the concerning 
finding s that he details .  
CURE ’s testi mony also dem onstrates that private equity ownership of a utility could 
potentially serve the public interest under very different circumstances than are offered by 
the Applicants in this proceeding.  Agreeing with  BlackRock ’s CEO on t he topic  of aligning 
retirement investment in energy companies , Mr. Ellis testified  that funding utility 
investment using Competitive Direct Equity  (CDE ) rather than exclusive  equity  lockups  
could serve Commissions, customers,  and priva te equity retirement fund investors alike.20  
 Mr. Baker, an expert on private equity who leads an organization that provides 
information and analysis of the social and environmental impacts  of private investors’  
acquisition and restructuring of businesses  and infrastructure,21 similarly found that the 
proposed acquisition would not likely provide any of the benefits asserted in  Applicant  
submissions and  testimony . Based on information in this record and research and available 
information on private equity investment, Mr. Baker found that this transaction could 
 
20 Ex. CURE -601 ( Mark Ellis Direct Testimony ), at 58 (discussing BlackRock CEO ’s 
statement ), 51–62 (regarding CDE ). While the Commission likely could not impose CDE 
as a condition of this acquisition, there is some value in understanding how it could have 
been structured so as to not misalign the incentives of owners and customers, and to set 
financial expectations accu rately to assure continued investment without extracting 
excessive profits from customers. Rejecting this application as contrary to the public 
interest does not prevent the Applicants from returning with a changed proposal that 
aligns better with Minnesot a’s needs, customer protection, and with a large number of 
private equity investors overseeing retirement accounts.  
21 Ex. CURE -600 ( Schedule JB -1, Jim Baker  Experience and Qualifications ); id. (Jim Baker 
Direct Testimony) , at 1. 
 
 
 
 11 exacerbate costs for raising capital  as opposed to MP’s current public market source s for 
such funds.22  
Mr. Baker  also discussed the  standard  private equity playbook, how it makes 
companies , including energy companies and utilities , more fragile and exposed to 
economic shock, and how it generally drives up debt levels in acquired companies.23 He did 
not find any evidence in the application or Applicant testimony,  nor in responses to 
discovery  requests,  that rebutted these concern s or indicate d that the Partners had any 
intention to deviate from this  regular playbook.24  
Due to the potentially precedent -setting nature of a private equity takeover of one 
of Minnesota’s public utilities , it is imperative that the Applicants be held to the highest 
standard to protect the public interest going forward as the state experiences an energy 
revolution under the CFS. CURE believes that the Commission should take this opportunity 
to affirm that for something to be “consistent with the public interest” it must substantially 
and meaningfully benefit  the public , not merely be non -harmful to utility customers and 
other interests of Minnesotans . The Commission’s overall mission is to serve the public, 
not to merely passively observe as legal monopolies extract value from Minnesota 
businesses  and residential customers. In accordance with the agency’s public  mission, it is 
appropriate to set a high bar that requires improvement with every approved utility 
transaction over $1,000,000 in value.

 12 II. The proposed acquisition  will harm customers and Minnesota  
A. The Applicant s’ valuation  of Minnesota Power is inflated, leading to an 
excessive  purchase price for ALLETE, aggravated by a large premium  
 
In order to comply with the legislature’s requirements that this transaction be 
“consistent with the public interest” the Commission is tasked with taking “ into 
consideration the reasonable value of the property, plant, or securities to be acquired or 
disposed of .”25 This requirement makes logical sense : without knowing what the value of 
MP is the Commission cannot assure that captured customers are well served by the 
financial implications of the transaction. Stated another way, if the price is too high and 
customers will have to bear the risk or cost associated with that incorrect valuation, then 
this acquisition cannot be consistent with the public interest.  
This is why the Applicants ’ witness testimony regarding ROE is blatantly incorrect  
when it states  that COE/ ROE issues are not germane to this proceeding.26 Without first 
addressing excessive ROE it is not possible for the Commission to assess the reasonable 
value of the transaction and determine whether it is in the public interest.  
Mr. Ellis’s testimony demonstrates that the proposed acquisition overvalues the 
company by approximately $1.5 billion .27 This windfall  will go to  ALLETE’s current owners, 
their public shareholders, and will only be recoverable from the customers who are left 
behind to deal with the Partners as the new owners of MP. As Mr. Ellis explained:  
No witness disputes that ALLETE shareholders will be walking away with a 
$1.5-billion  profit over rate base value if this transaction proceeds.  As I have

Development),  at 19.  
27 Ex. CURE -601 (Mark Ellis Direct Testimony), at 21, n.26.  
 
 
 
 13 just demonstrated, unless  the Commission reduces MP ’s ROE significantly in 
other regulatory proceedings, this profit  will ultimately come out of 
customers ’ pockets. We should ask ourselves: What have  ALLETE ’s current 
owners and managers done to deserve this windfall?28 
 
It cannot be that the current owners of MP deserve such a large payout merely because the 
CFS has changed utility management  for all utilities, nor  can they deserve this me rely 
because they sought and found private equity  buyers  who plan to squee ze out higher profits 
than p ublic owners would have .29 
Without properly valuing this company the Commission may be put in a similar no -
win situation that befell the regulators of UPPCO in Michigan. In a schedule to Mr. Baker’s 
testimony, an analysis  by Incident Energy LLC  titled “Understanding the Upper Peninsula 
Power Company Dilemma” lays out how Michigan’s Public Service Commission “has been 
doomed to play a reoccurring role as [UPPCO ’s] regulator[.] ”30 The analysis describes 
UPPCO’s initial 2014 private equity purchase  proposal for stock with a  price $14.2 million 
above book value, but ultimately the deal w as for UPPCO on an asset basis at a premium 
of $52.1 million above book value.31 The report provides analysis of why a cquiring the utility 
at a “substantial price for UPPCO over its book value” with a “substantial amount of debt ,” 
would  lead to financial danger if the utility’s future cash flow is not sufficient to cover debt  
for both the utility and its parent company’s  debt from the acquisition.32

 14 It turns out that this analy st’s report from  2019 has been predictive of UPPCO ’s 
continuing poor perform ance regarding maintain ing stability and reasonable rates. 
Following the 2014  acquisition of  UPPCO by private  equity  its rates have continued to climb 
rapidly, and the utility was resold within nine years  to another private equity owner  who 
has sought even higher rates .33 The high valuation of UPPCO in 2014 and sale to private 
equity owners with distinct interests that do not align well with customer interests  
subsequently put Michigan ’s state regulator in a difficult position in future rate cases and 
acquisition dockets —the original purchase price and su bsequent  incentives of the owners 
led to outcomes that have been contrary to the public interest.   
It is true that in order to properly value this and other utilities going forward, the 
Commission will also need to reassess  economic  analysis in other dockets. But the fact that 
the Commission is tasked with making sound judgements in rate cases in no way absolves 
it of the need to do so in this docket  as well . To the extent that the Applicants ’ witnesses 
would prefer that the Commission merely take the sale price as a fact and not question 
whether it is too high, this is contrary to what the legislature has tasked the Commission 
with doing . In order to value this company correctly, an d allow it to operate optimally for 
its customers going forward, the Commission should take this opportunity to set its value 
consistent with book value, and begin a process of reevaluating excessive ROE assumptions 
that may have been made in the past.

 15 B. Private equity investment normally seeks short -term excessive profits through 
predictable risky behaviors  
 
When private equity companies invest in energy companie s and utilities, the 
investors’ unique set of interests do not naturally align with stable and reliable utility 
outcomes for customers. Private equity investors seek profits in excess of regulated utilities ’ 
authorized rates of return, and value short term cash flow above long -term viability and 
predictability of utility performance.  
Mr. Baker’s testimony and materials he cites lay  out this conundrum —private equity 
companies, including private infrastructure investors like the Partners, seek to extract high 
profits out of entities they only own for a short hold period.34 In the case of GIP V, the fund 
used to acquire ALLETE, the target return is 15 to 20 percent , considerably above a utility’s 
normal authorized rate of return.35 Additionally, GIP V  only has a hold period of 10 years 
plus two one -year extensions, and that hold period includes both the time to acquire a 
company and the actual ownership years —with ownership lasting on average 4 -6 years.36 
These types of investors  then, in addition to any debt used for the acquisition, regularly 
engage in “dividend recapitalization” which is  producing  dividends for investors with debts 
placed on the acquired company.37 Large short -term profits are therefore possible through

37 Ex. CURE -600 (Jim Baker Direct Testimony),  at 5-6. 
 
 
 
 16 debt leveraging, rather than through a utility’s normal sources of income that pay more 
modest dividends to public shareholders.38 
In addition  to the concerns and analysis Mr. Baker offered , Mr. Ellis found that the 
Partners were engaged in a “buy-build -bail” strategy , and described the Partners’ “powerful 
financial incentives to inflate rate base as fast as possible , to the detriment of customers. ”39 
This i s con sistent with Mr. Baker’s analysis regarding private equity underinvesting in 
business areas that are not immediately  profitable , and only focus ing on activities that 
maximize cash flow.40 
 When public companies are taken private, their employees often suffer.41 The risk

Management had issued erroneous financial reports , making it impossible to secure new 
financing and  causing their independent accountant to resign .44 Prior to the bankruptc y, 
SunPower laid off around a thousand employees.45 Many SunPower customers were left

ii. Cost of CFS implementation  
 
Ostensibly, one of the leading justifications  for this acquisition is that MP faces a 
new reality under the CFS and will need capital in order to transition to 100 percent carbon -
free energy by 2040 . However, the CFS does not require decarbonization at any price , it 
 
64 Ex. CURE -600 ( Jim Baker Direct Testimony ), at 28.  
65 See Ex. CURE -602 ( Jim Baker Surrebuttal Testimony ), at 7 –8.  
 
 
 
 23 contains offset options as well as “off ramps ” should the Commission approve them . If 
Minnesota utilities only present the  Commission the  most expensive options for energy 
generation, it is highly likely that they will either achieve carbon -free energy at too high a 
cost or miss the mark because they do not meet the Commission ’s other goals of 
affordability and r eliability . 
One clear way for the Commission to make such default or cost -overrun s less likely 
would be to assure that every dollar of ratepayer money is having the maximum effect . 
Rate s should be reinvested to the maximum,  and not  taken off as excessive profits that will 
not be used to keep utility bills low  or sustain investment  in low-cost resources .  
A clear way to move all utilities towards least -cost compliance with the CFS is to 
eliminate excessive ROEs and to value MP and other utilities consistent with their book 
value. This is explained in detail in a schedule to Mr. Ellis’s testimony, a report he authored 
for The American Economic Liberties Project  titled “Rate of Return Equals Cost of Capital: 
A Simple, Fair Formula to Stop Investor -Owned Utilities From Overcharging the Public.”66 
In the report Mr. Ellis explains that setting rate of return above cost of capital is counter to 
U.S. Supreme Court precedent and unjustly enriches utility investors at the expense of 
utility customers.67 He calculates, on average across all IOUs, “Bringing  RORs into 
compliance with the regulatory standard would enable every dollar of utility revenue  
collected from customers for capital investment to go approximately 25% further — 25% 
 
66 Ex. CURE -601 (Schedule ME -2).  
67 Id. at 5.  
 
 
 
 24 more  bang for every customer buck put toward utility investment. ”68 Minnesota, with the 
push in the right direction by the CFS, could really use the additional proverbial bang for 
its ratep ayer bucks ; keeping customer bills as low as possible while achieving carbon free 
energy by 2040 is made all the more achievable if the Commission resets its past 
precedents69 on ROE and valuation as described in this report and Mr. Ellis’s testimony in 
this case.

CONCLUSION  
 CURE respectfully requests that the Judge and Commission deny this acquisition as 
being contrary to the public interes t. The purchase price exceeds a reasonable value for MP 
and would ultimately b e borne by custo mers through r ates or decre ased utility 
performance  and financial risk . The risks associated with this transaction are many, and 
the benefit su ggested by the Applicant s appear s to be flimsy at best, or illus ory at worst. 
MP customers , businesses who rely on MP and it s consistent serv ice, our environment, and 
our future sustainable growth depends on the  Commission upholding the public interest 
and assuring that this transaction is not rubber stamped  without demonstrated benefits for 
Minnesota . 
 As much as the CFS is a historic and necessary standard, it is not an absolute, and it 
allows utilities many different paths to achieve  compliance. It will pose many unanticipated 
challenges for the Commission over the next fifteen years, and potentially beyond. The CFS 
requires that the energy system clean up, but it doesn’t say with rigid specificity how this 
will be accomplished. The A pplicants offer a single path for MP as a take -it-or-leave it, 
costly, and que stionable plan for the n orthland. They are sophisticated investors, and we 
 
 
 
 27 should hol d them to higher standards than they apparently hold themselves. Rejecting this 
application will allow them to reconsider how they could accomplish the policy of th e CFS  
and recoup reasonable profits, without harming the public interest.

INTRODUCTION 
In this proceeding, ALLETE, Inc., the owner of Minnesota Power Company (the 
“Company”) , seeks authorization from the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 
(“Commission”) for ALLETE’S proposed acquisition (“Acquisition”) by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board (“CPP”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) (together, the “Partners”).  
ALLETE and the Partners characterize the proposed A cquisition as a win -win 
transaction. They claim that the Acquisition is needed to improve the Company’s access to 
capital  over the next twenty years , that it will facilitate the Company’s transition to clean energy, 
and that it will not result in higher costs or greater risks for ratepayers. The record evidence 
refutes each of these conten tions. The Partners do not make a binding commitment to provide the 
Company with capital or to fund clean energy projects. The Partners do not commit to own the Company for a minimum period. And the Partners’ pursuit of higher returns is likely to drive larger rate increases for customers. The actual terms outlined in the Acquisition agreement and in 
various nonpublic documents do not match the rosy story that the Company and Partners present in their public statements. Documents obtained in discovery reveal the Partners’ true intentions, demonstrating the Acquisition’s illusory benefits and profound risks for the Company and its 
ratepayers.   
Minnesota law requires the Commission to evaluate whether the proposed A cquisition is 
in the public interest, weighi ng the transaction’s potential harms against its potential benefits. 
The evidence in this proceeding, including an analysis conducted by Sierra Club’s expert witness, Courtney Lane of Synapse Energy Economics, shows that the proposed A cquisition is 
likely to increase costs and risks while offering no benefits for Minnesota Power ratepayers :

 First, the A cquisition may delay  the Company’s transition to renewable energy, prolong 
operation of the costly coal -fired  Boswell Generating Station , and threaten the Company’s 
compliance with Minnesota’s Carbon- Free Standard . Second, the Partners have not committed to 
provide capital to the Company, creating a risk that they may under-invest in the Company in the 
future, and the Company has not demonstrated that this A cquisition is a better alternative to 
obtaining capital on public markets. Third, there is an overinvestment risk as the Partners’ 
pursuit of higher returns will likely pressure the Company to engage in excessive capital spending and forego lowest-cost opt ions, resulting in larger rate increases for customers.  Fourth, 
the Acquisition would reduce local control, as the ALLETE board would be dominated by the Partners, who will likely favor their own interests over ratepayers. Finally, the Acquisition would undermine transparency, as the Partners would not provide financial disclosures comparable to those made by ALLETE.  
ALLETE and the Partners have not demonstrated that the y need the A cquisition  to obtain 
capital , or that the Acquisition would provide any rate payer benefits, let alone benefits sufficient 
to outweigh the substantial harms and risks that would result from the proposal. Sierra Club therefore recommends that the Commission not approve the proposed A cquisition.  Deals that 
appear too good to be true usually aren’t, and indeed, in this case the Acquisition is not.

Power is an oper ating division of ALLETE that provides electric service to approximately

management  sectors.17 GIP is funding its share of the proposed Acquisition through two funds,

II. IDENTITY AND INTERESTS OF SIERRA CLUB  
 Sierra Club is a national nonprofit environmental organization working to promote healthy communities, protect air and water quality, limit the adverse effe cts of climate change, 
and advance the transition to renewable energy. Sierra Club has over 14,000 members in Minnesota, many of whom are Minnesota Power customers.
42 Sierra Club has consistently 
advocated for Minnesota Power to transition away from coal- fired and gas- fired electricity 
generation and invest in affordable, renewable energy sources, and seeks to ensure that Minnesota Power complies with the state’s Carbon Free Standard.

ARGUMENT  
The record in this case —including the Company’s own statements as well as the 
testimony of Witness Lane and other intervenor witnesses—shows that the proposed Acquisition 
is likely to increase costs and risks while offering no benefits for Minnesota ratepayers . First, the 
Acquisition may delay Minnesota Power’s transition to renewable energy, prolong operation of 
the costly coal -fired Bosw ell Generating Station, and threaten the Company’s compliance with 
the Carbon Free Standard. Second, the Partners have not committed to provide capital to the Company, and the Company has not demonstrated that this A cquisition is a better alternative to 
obtaining capital on public markets. Third, the Partners’ pursuit of higher returns would likely pressure the Company to engage in excessive capital spending and forego lowest-cost options, resulting in larger rate increases for customers. Fourth, the Acquisition would reduce local control, as the ALLETE board would be dominated by the Partners, who will likely favor their

I. THE ACQUISITION COULD THREATEN THE COMPANY’S ABILITY TO 
COMPLY WITH THE CARBON FREE STANDARD AND INCREASE THE RISK OF DELAYED CLOSURE OF THE BOSWELL COAL UNITS . 
The Company and the Partners claim that the A cquisitio n is intended to finance the 
Company’s transition to clean energy and have pointed to the need to comply with the Carbon 
Free Standard as a justification for the A cquisition. But the actual terms of the Acquisition do not 
match this rhetoric: the Partners do not commit to achieve the emissions reductions called for by the Carbon Free Standard as a condition of the A cquisition , nor do they commit to finance any 
particular amount of clean energy. Moreover, t he Acquisition could harm Minnesota Power’s 
ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard in several ways. First, while the Partners currently claim to support Minnesota Power’s planned transition to clean energy sources, there is a risk that the Partners’ goals may shift away from clean energy, and there is no guarantee that the Partners will not seek to change the Company’s planned coal retirement dates after the Acquisition is complete. Second, the Partners could sell the Company before the Boswell coal units are retired, and the Company’s next owners may not commit to a clean energy transition.  
Given the lack of firm commitments in the Acquisition agreement and the uncertainties associated with the A cquisition, there is a r isk that the Company’s planned energy transition may 
be much less “clean” than the Company claims.  
A. The Partners H ave Not Made a B inding Commitment to Achieve the Carbon Free 
Standard. 
Throughout the application and testimony, the Company and the Partners repeatedly 
claim that they are committed to achieving the clean energy transition needed to meet the Carbon

II. MINNESOTA POWER  HAS NOT DEMONSTRATED THAT THE 
ACQUISITION WOULD BENEFIT RATEP AYERS  OR THAT IT WOULD 
MEET THE COMPANY’S CAPITAL NEEDS . 
ALLETE bears the burden to show that the A cquisition is consistent with the public 
interest.95 Under the public interest standard, the Commission must consider whether the 
proposed Acquisition would benefit ratepayers and the public, and if so, whether those benefits 
outweigh potential harms.96 “In determining whether a transaction is in the public interest” under 
Minn. Stat.  § 216B.50, subd. 1, “the overall benefits of the [transaction] should exceed the 
overall detriments.”97 Here, ALLETE has not demonstrated a need fo r the A cquisition, or that it 
would substantially benefit ratepayers . Sierra Club does not dispute that Minnesota Power needs 
access to some level of capital. However, the Company has not had difficulty raising capital on public markets in the past . The Company has not shown that this A cquisition would meet the 
Company’s future  capital needs , or that it would b enefit ratepayers . 
A. The Commission S hould C onsider Whether the A cquisition  Is Needed . 
The Company argues that the Commission is not required consider whether there is any 
need for the Acquisition.

CONCLUSION  
The evidence in this proceeding shows that the Acquisition is likely to result in numerous 
potential harms , costs, and risks fo r Minnesota Power ratepayers . The Partners would have an 
incentive to push for over- spending in order to maximize their returns, which will ultimately 
result in larger rate increases. The A cquisition may also delay Minnesota Power’s  
retirement of the Bosw ell coal units and the Company’s transition to renewable energy, 
imperiling compliance with the Carbon Free Standard . The Acquisition would also reduce local 
control, as the ALLETE board would be dominated by the Partners, and undermine transparency, as the Partners would not provide financial disclosures comparable to those made by ALLETE. 
ALLETE and the Partners have not demonstrated that the Acquisition would provide 
ratepayer benefits sufficient to outweigh the se substantial harms and risks. The Partn ers do not 
make a binding commitment to provide the Company with capital or to fund the Company’s clean energy transition . The various commitments and affirmations proposed by the P etitioners 
do not adequately mitigate these harms and risks. Indeed, many of those claimed commitments
